appropriate for age. The mother is mildly upset because her friend's baby, approximately of the same age as
hers, died recently in the crib. The cause remained unexplained even after autopsy. She asks for more
information about this incident and asks how to prevent it. What preventive measure has dramatically
decreased the incidence of this condition in the United States?
options: A. Sleeping infants on the side
B. Sleeping infants in prone position
C. Sleeping infants in supine position
explanation:
Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is the leading cause of mortality in infants aged between 1 month and
1 year in the United States. It is defined as the sudden, unexpected death of an infant that cannot be
explained by the history and a thorough post-mortem examination (i.e., review of medical history, investigation
of the scene of death, and complete autopsy). SIDS is more frequent in infants who are male, between 2-4
months of age, and of low socioeconomic status.
In 1992 the American Academy of Pediatrics recommended that infants be placed in a supine position while
sleeping to reduce the risk of SIDS. This measure proved to be highly effective, with the annual rate of SIDS
in the U.S. declining from 1.3-1.4/1000 live births before 1992, to 0.7/1000 live births in 1999. Similar
improvements have been noted in other countries.
(Choice A) Although the risk of SIDS are decreased in side-sleeping infants, studies have shown that its
occurrence is still twice as high than that of infants sleeping on their back.
(Choice B) Sleeping in the prone position increases the risk of SIDS.
(Choice D) Home monitors were widely used in the past to prevent SIDS because apnea was thought to be
its leading cause; however, studies failed to confirm this relation.
(Choices E and F) Modifiable risk factors which have been identified include poor prenatal care, maternal
tobacco and alcohol use, and prenatal drug use. Interventions that may contribute in reducing the risk for
SIDS include: (1) smoking cessation, (2) use of a crib that meets federal safety standards of softness,
malleability and rebreathing, (3) avoidance of overheating and over bundling, and (4) avoidance of bed
sharing.
Manipulating the smoking factor has not resulted in a significant decrease in the incidence of SIDS.
Furthermore, it is more difficult for parents to quit smoking than to ensure a safe sleep environment for their
infants.
Bed sharing with the parents should be avoided because this can actually be hazardous for the infant (e.g,
when parents smoke in bed or use any substance that may impair their alertness, such as alcohol and
drugs). Bed sharing with other persons (e.g., siblings) should also be avoided.
Educational Objective:
To prevent SIDS, infants should be placed on their backs (supine position) while sleeping. Home monitors do
not decrease the risk of SIDS.

question:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office due to abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea for the past two days. Her
immunizations are up to date. Her past medical history is unremarkable. On examination, she appears
lethargic and weak. Her skin turgor is poor, face and extremities are swollen, and skin appears yellow.
Abdominal examination shows moderate non-localized, abdominal pain. Laboratory studies show:
Hb                    6.4 g/dL
Hct                   26.9%
Platelets              45,000/mm3
Creatinine            2.3 mg/dL
Total bilirubin         5.0 mg/dL
What is the most common complication of the patient's condition?
explanation:
Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by a toxin released from Escherichia coli. The toxin enters the
systemic circulation and injures the endothelial cells in the kidney. When there is progressive elevation of
BUN and creatinine, the chances for improvement of the kidneys’ function is poor. When the kidneys are
damaged, the mortality is 5-10%.
(Choice B) The liver is not directly damaged by the toxin in HUS. The jaundice seen in HUS is due to
hemolysis, and not liver injury.
(Choice C) The bone marrow is relatively spared from the toxin. The thrombocytopenia and anemia are due
to intravascular destruction of the RBCs and platelets.
(Choice D) Pneumonia is not a clinical feature of HUS
(Choice E) Bowel obstruction does not occur with HUS. The usual presentation is abdominal cramping and
bloody diarrhea.
Educational Objective:
The organ system with the highest morbidity and mortality after HUS is the kidneys.

question:
A 13-year-old boy is brought by his mother to the office due to progressive muscle weakness over the past 2
months. The weakness was mild at first, but subsequently worsened and led to significant motor incapacity.
His medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals temporal wasting, thin cheeks, emaciated
extremities, atrophy of the thenar and hypothenar eminences, upper lip in the shape of an inverted V, and
testicular atrophy. Upon contraction of the thenar and hypothenar muscles, delayed relaxation is noted.
Neurologic examination reveals normal deep tendon reflexes and a negative Babinski sign. What is the most
likely mode of genetic transmission of the patient's condition?
explanation:
This patient has myotonic muscular dystrophy (MMD), an autosomal dominant disease which is also known
as Steinert disease. It is the second most common muscular dystrophy in the United States. The pathology
is distinct in that all types of muscles (i.e., smooth, striated, cardiac) are involved. The above case
presentation is typical: the patient initially appears normal at birth, then slowly develops muscle weakness
and progressive muscle wasting, especially in the distal muscles of the hands, posterior forearm muscles,
and anterior compartment of the lower legs. The characteristic facial appearance is illustrated above:
temporal wasting, thin cheeks, and an upper lip in the shape of an inverted V. Pertinent physical findings
include emaciated extremities, atrophy of the thenar and hypothenar eminences, proximal muscle weakness,
positive Gowers sign, winged scapula, and myotonia. Myotonia is defined as delayed muscle relaxation, and
the classic example is the inability to release the hand after a handshake. In addition, abnormalities of the
endocrine, immunologic, and nervous systems occur. Endocrine manifestations include diabetes mellitus,
testicular atrophy, frontal baldness and hypothyroidism.
Educational Objective:
Myotonic muscular dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder and is the second most common muscular
dystrophy. Myotonia is defined as delayed muscle relaxation, and the classic example is the inability to
release the hand after a handshake.

question:
A one-day-old infant with Down syndrome has developed persistent vomiting. He was delivered vaginally at
34 weeks without any complications. On examination, he appears dehydrated and slightly tachypneic. His
abdomen is soft and not distended. Abdominal x-ray reveals two large distinct air bubbles, but there are no
dilated bowel loops or air fluid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
explanation:
The above case is a classic example of duodenal atresia. Suspect duodenal atresia when the patient
has bile-stained vomitus, no abdominal distension, dehydration and Down syndrome. Vomiting usually
begins in the first 24 to 48 hours after birth. The mother may have a history of polyhydramnios. The typical
abdominal x-ray finding is the "double bubble" sign (dilated stomach and duodenum). The treatment is
decompression with a nasogastric tube, correction of electrolyte abnormalities and surgery.
(Choice A) Pyloric stenosis is most common in first-born children, and patients may have a positive family
history. Features include non-bilious projectile vomiting after feeding, palpable olive-shaped abdominal mass,
and visible gastric peristalsis. Hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis is typical. The diagnosis is confirmed with
ultrasonography.
(Choice B) Gastroesophageal reflux is common in infants, and usually occurs in a thriving baby. The
vomiting episodes are seen after feeding, and the vomitus is not bilious and rarely contains blood. The infant
may present with recurrent pneumonias or cough. A 24-hour pH probe, contrast swallow study, or
endoscopy may reveal the diagnosis.
(Choice C) Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) usually presents in infancy with coughing, vomiting and gagging
after feeding. Respiratory distress is common after feeding, and frothy bubbles are seen in the oral cavity
even after suctioning. The condition may be associated with VACTERL syndromes, and the mother may
have a history of polyhydramnios.
(Choice D) Although malrotation or atresia of the bowel may also present with recurrent vomiting and
bile-stained vomitus, the abdomen is usually distended and the typical x-ray finding includes loops of dilated
bowel with air fluid levels.
Educational Objective:
Suspect duodenal atresia when the patient has bile-stained vomitus, no abdominal distension, dehydration,
double bubble sign, and Down syndrome. Vomiting usually begins in the first 24 to 48 hours after birth.

question:
A 2-year-old child is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of failure to thrive and chronic
diarrhea. His diarrhea is "almost continuous”, and he also has recurrent episodes of fever. He was initially
quite well and was on the 60th percentile for weight; however, for the past seven months, he didn't seem to
grow and failed to gain weight. Over the past three months, he fell to the 3rd percentile for weight. His
parents deny any use of drugs, but they drink occasionally. His mother mentions that her former boyfriend
was a heroin addict. Physical examination reveals oral thrush, generalized lymphadenopathy and eczema.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma infiltrating small intestine
explanation:
There is currently more than 100,000 cases of AIDS in the United States. Women represent 18% of all
cases, and among them, 85% are of childbearing age. Approximately 7,000 HIV-infected women give birth
annually to 1000 to 2000 infected infants. For these reasons, HIV testing is standardly offered to all pregnant
women in the first trimester. There is no change in the frequency of prenatal visits of the infected mother,
unless a specific indication is present; therefore, vigilance is necessary to detect the early signs of
opportunistic infections and any deterioration in the course of the disease. The progression of the disease is
monitored through regular measurements of CD4 count, and the decision for prevention of opportunistic
infections should be made accordingly. Invasive procedures are avoided to decrease the risk of transmission
to the infant. Pregnant women with HIV seem to be at higher risk of infectious complications such as
postpartum infections, opportunistic infections and sexually transmitted diseases; however, the overall
course of the disease does not seem to be altered.
In neonates, serologic testing is not useful for HIV diagnosis because of the passage of maternal antibodies
to the fetal circulation through the placenta. PCR, viral culture and p24 antigen testing are more appropriate;
HIV infection is confirmed if at least two of these tests are positive. The disease progresses more rapidly in
neonates and infants. Infected infants are generally asymptomatic at birth. The first symptoms usually
appear in the first month and include persistent oral thrush, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.
More severe symptoms subsequently develop, such as intractable diarrhea, refractory infections and failure
to thrive. Half of HIV positive children develop AIDS in the first year of life, with an average survival rate of 3
years.
(Choice A) Toxoplasmosis does not manifest with thrush or an immunodeficiency syndrome. At this age,
mental retardation, learning disabilities and chorioretinitis are more characteristic.
(Choice B) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma manifests most commonly with abdominal symptoms such as
abdominal distention, ascites, urinary tract obstruction and intestinal obstruction. The infant in this case has
signs of immunodeficiency (i.e., recurrent fever, thrush and intractable diarrhea), and may be at higher risk for
developing a lymphoma afterwards; however, the most plausible diagnosis at this time is HIV infection.
(Choice D) Miliary tuberculosis manifests with respiratory symptoms and meningitis. Immunodeficiency is
more specific for HIV infection, especially since the mother's ex-boyfriend is a heroin addict.
(Choice E) Children with malabsorptive disease do not present with immunodeficiency symptoms.
Educational Objective:
HIV testing is standardly offered to all pregnant women in the first trimester to prevent possible transmission
to the infant. Persistent oral thrush, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly may be the presenting
symptoms of AIDS in infants.

question:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because she became partially unconscious,
lethargic and febrile. Her mother claims that "she suddenly took a turn for the worse" 24 hours ago after an
upper respiratory tract infection. She has no allergies, and was not taking oral antibiotics. Her blood
pressure is 60/45mm Hg and pulse is 120/min. On examination, she appears emaciated and lethargic.
Despite numerous attempts, it is impossible to start a peripheral intravenous line, and the child's condition
continues to deteriorate. What is the best next step to obtain IV access in this patient?
explanation:
Whenever intravenous access cannot be obtained in emergent pediatric cases, intraosseous access should
be attempted next. Intraosseous cannulation can be performed quickly in the ED, even with less than optimal
light, assistance and choice of equipment. Another advantage is that this technique does not require the
precision required for cannulation of small vessels, yet provides a cannula large enough to deliver adequate
fluids. This route can be used in emergencies for 24 to 48 hours, at which point another intravenous route
should have been obtained. Associated complications such as osteomyelitis are rare. In adults, the
intraosseous route can also be used, but their greater bone density makes it difficult to penetrate the bone.
(Choice A) Central line placement in children and infants should only be done by highly-skilled individuals,
and is therefore not recommended in the ED. Subclavian line placement in children is associated with a high
incidence of complications such as pneumothorax and hemothorax.
(Choice C) Jugular vein cut down in the ED is not recommended. This is difficult to perform in the absence
of adequate lighting and appropriate instruments. Furthermore, the jugular vein area is not the recommended
site for cut down as many important structures are found in the neck area.
(Choice D) Femoral vein cannulation can be done and is a relatively easy technique; however, many do not
prefer this technique in children because of possible perineal contamination. Furthermore, lines placed in the
groin area make it difficult for patients to be mobile, and bleeding from the site is a constant problem.
(Choice E) Fluids should never be placed down the endotracheal tube because this leads to aspiration and
symptoms of ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome). Only in urgent situations should medications
such as epinephrine or lidocaine be placed down the endotracheal tube.
Educational Objective:
Whenever intravenous access cannot be obtained in emergent pediatric cases, intraosseous access should
be attempted next.

question:
A 12-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever.
He was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis when he was five years old. He is currently not taking any
medications. His temperature is 39.4C (103F), blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and
respirations are 30/min. He is excessively using his accessory respiratory muscles. Lung auscultation
reveals bilateral lower lobe crackles and expiratory wheezing. Pulse oximetry shows SaO2 of 85% that
improves to 92% after oxygen supplementation. Which of the following antibiotics or combinations is the best
choice for this patient?
explanation:
This cystic fibrosis patient is suffering from an acute exacerbation of lung disease, and his presentation (i.e,
prominent shortness of breath, excessive use of accessory respiratory muscles, hypotension) is suggestive
of a severe attack. The most common etiologic agent is Pseudomonas aeruginosa, although a variety of
other agents have been implicated (e.g, S. aureus and H. influenzae). The treatment is rapid administration
of empiric antibiotics, and the usual choice is a combination of two agents with coverage against
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, (i.e., ceftazidime or a penicillin derivative such as ticarcillin + an aminoglycoside
such as amikacin or gentamicin).
(Choice C) The other drugs that are effective against Pseudomonas are cefepime and imipenem/cilastatin
combination. Imipenem/cilastatin is effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but is used as a second-line
drug. Double coverage (combination antibiotics) is important, because of the remarkable resistance of this
organism to most antibiotics, and its ability to develop further resistance during the course of therapy.
(Choice B) The addition of an anti-staphylococcal antibiotic (e.g. nafcillin or vancomycin) depends on the
results of the culture.
(Choice E) Oral ciprofloxacin covers Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but it is not appropriate for severe
exacerbations, wherein intravenous antibiotics are usually employed. The new generation fluoroquinolones
(e.g., levofloxacin, gatifloxacin) do not have good coverage against Pseudomonas.
(Choice D) Clindamycin is effective against anaerobes, and has little role in the treatment of such patients.
Educational Objective:
The treatment for an acute severe exacerbation of lung disease in a cystic fibrosis patient is intravenous
antibiotic therapy with coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (usually a combination of two drugs, such
as penicillin/cephalosporin + aminoglycoside).

question:
A 4-day old preterm male neonate is being managed in the neonatal intensive care unit. He was born in the
34th week of gestation via lower segment caesarian section. On the first day of life, he developed tachypnea,
grunting and nasal flaring. Chest x-rays showed a ground glass appearance of both lungs. He underwent
endotracheal intubation and therapy with intravenous fluids, positive pressure ventilation, and intravenous
antibiotics. He consequently showed remarkable improvement; however, he is currently beginning to have
increased gastric residues. What is the most likely cause for this child's increased gastric residues?
explanation:
Increased gastric residues in a preterm neonate is highly suspicious for necrotizing
enterocolitis. The condition usually presents at 3-10 days after birth, and is due to bowel wall injury resulting
from perinatal asphyxia. The diagnosis requires a high index of suspicion. Treatment depends on the degree
of bowel involvement and severity of presentation. Preterm neonates are at high risk for other complications
such as hyaline membrane disease, which presents with respiratory distress and ground glass appearance
of the lungs on chest x-rays.
(Choice A) Tracheo-esophageal fistula presents with excessive drooling, choking, coughing, and cyanosis
due to aspiration of feedings.
(Choice C) Bilious vomiting without abdominal distention is the cardinal sign for duodenal atresia.
(Choice D) Clinical features of meconium aspiration syndrome include thick, greenish amniotic fluid in the
mouth and throat at birth, accompanied by cyanosis and respiratory distress.
(Choice E) Pyloric stenosis is characterized by projectile nonbilious vomiting and palpation of an
olive-shaped mass immediately after the infant has vomited.
Educational Objective:
Increased gastric residues in a preterm neonate is highly suspicious for necrotizing enterocolitis.

question:
A 5-day-old male term neonate has been passing maroon-colored stools for the past three days, along with
frequent episodes of vomiting. He is being breastfed by his mother, who is an asthmatic. His vital signs are
within normal limits. The physical examination is unremarkable. Stool examination is positive for RBCs and
eosinophils. What is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
explanation:
Milk protein intolerance may present with vomiting and bloody diarrhea. Stools may show RBCs and
eosinophils, and there may be a family history of an atopic disorder. It is a hypersensitivity reaction to cow's
milk proteins, and therefore usually occurs in babies who are fed with cow's milk; however, it may occur in
breastfed babies, as the mother's milk may contain proteins from ingested cow's milk.
(Choice A) Necrotizing enterocolitis occurs in premature babies. It is an acute condition, and abdominal
examination shows distension and tenderness.
(Choice B) In viral gastroenteritis, the associated diarrhea is usually non-bloody.
(Choice C) Meckel's diverticulum typically presents as painless melena in a child who is approximately 2
years of age.
(Choice E) Hirschsprung's disease may present with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life
and/or failure to thrive.
Educational Objective:
Milk protein intolerance should be suspected when a neonate presents with bloody diarrhea, eosinophils in
the stool, and a positive family history of atopy.

question:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the office due to significant steatorrhea and failure to thrive. She has a poor
appetite and general malaise. Her past medical history is significant for prolonged neonatal jaundice and
numerous respiratory tract infections. On examination, she looks a little underweight and has a runny nose.
Auscultation reveals mild wheezing and diminished air entry in both lungs. Clubbing is visible on both hands.
What is the best diagnostic test for this patient?
explanation:
In childhood, cystic fibrosis (CF) has a wide range of manifestations, such as anemia, heat intolerance,
steatorrhea, wheezing, recurrent infections, hemoptysis, clubbing and rectal prolapse. In this child with
failure to thrive, steatorrhea, and a history of neonatal jaundice, it is imperative to rule out CF. The
steatorrhea of this child may be due to pancreatic insufficiency. A positive sweat chloride test is diagnostic,
but it must be repeated twice to avoid any false positives or negatives. Genetic studies should be done when
the sweat test is equivocal. Prenatal screening should be offered to high-risk families. The treatment is a
high-calorie diet, pancreatic enzyme replacements and fat-soluble vitamins. The current median survival is
30 years. Complications of prolonged CF include gallstones, cirrhosis with portal hypertension and
pancreatic fibrosis.
(Choice A) Blood cultures cannot confirm the diagnosis of CF, but may be done as part of the work-up when
sepsis is suspected.
(Choice B) Sputum cultures are not diagnostic of CF, but allow for the identification of the organism
responsible for the infections. The most common organisms are S. aureus, Pseudomonas and H. influenza.
CF patients must be kept up to date with their immunizations.
(Choice C) This patient's pancreatic insufficiency is most likely due to a lack of pancreatic enzymes. CT
scan of the abdomen will generally not reveal any pathology.
(Choice E) Liver enzymes are usually normal in CF patients. Furthermore, even if the enzymes
are elevated, these are not diagnostic of CF.
Educational Objective:
In childhood, cystic fibrosis has a wide range of manifestations, such as anemia, heat intolerance,
steatorrhea, wheezing, recurrent infections, hemoptysis, clubbing and rectal prolapse. A positive sweat
chloride test confirms the diagnosis.
*Cystic fibrosis is an extremely high yield topic for USMLE. You need to have in-depth knowledge about this
topic *

question:
A 6-year-old obese girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who is concerned that the child does not
exercise and constantly eats. The mother has tried to enroll her in gym and fitness classes, but without
success. The mother seems helpless and asks for your help. Which of the following is not a complication of
obesity later in life?
explanation:
Obesity is a condition defined by weight that is 20% more than expected for age and height. It is a common
problem in North America. In children, caliper determination of skin fold thickness percent fat body
composition is a more sensitive diagnostic tool than weight measurement. There are many causes of
obesity, and these include Prader-Willi syndrome, Carpenter syndrome, Pickwickian syndrome, Cushing
syndrome and hypothyroidism. Obese patients tend to develop type 2 diabetes as they grow older, and their
diabetes eventually becomes insulin-resistant. Type 1 diabetes is congenitally acquired, and is due to an
autoimmune destruction of the pancreatic islets.
(Choice A) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is seen in obese children more often. These children present
with anterior thigh pain.
(Choice C) Childhood obesity is associated with hypertension and increased LDL.
(Choice D) Obesity may lead to psychological problems such as poor self-esteem due to teasing, and an
unhealthy coping mechanism.
(Choice E) Obesity is a risk factor for uterine cancer. It can cause gynecomastia in boys, and is
associated with polycystic ovarian syndrome and early menarche in girls.
Educational Objective:
Childhood obesity is a risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes later in life. (Note: The option B in the question says Type I diabetes, which is incorrect, making it the answer.)

question:
A 30-minute-old male newborn is noted to have central cyanosis. He was born to a 16-year-old white female
at 28 weeks gestation. His respirations are rapid and shallow at 70/min. His other vital signs are stable. On
examination, there is audible grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and duskiness. On
auscultation, fine rales are heard over the lung bases. Nasal oxygenation does not improve his cyanosis. A
chest roentgenogram shows fine reticular granularity, predominantly in the lower lobes. Arterial blood gas
analysis shows evidence of hypoxemia and metabolic acidosis. What is the most likely diagnosis of this
patient?
options: A. Transient tachypnea of the newborn
C. Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN)
explanation:
Hyaline membrane disease (HMD) occurs primarily in premature infants. It occurs in 60-80% of infants who
are less than 28 weeks gestational age. The decreased production and secretion of surfactant is the primary
cause. In the absence of surfactant, atelectasis ensues and results in perfused but non-ventilated alveoli,
and consequently hypoxia. HMD characteristically presents as tachypnea, prominent grunting, intercostal
and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and duskiness within a few minutes after birth. Breath sounds may
be normal or diminished with a harsh tubular quality, and on deep inspiration, fine rales may be heard,
especially over the lung bases posteriorly. The characteristic chest-x ray finding demonstrates fine reticular
granularity of the lung parenchyma. The clinical course, x-ray of the chest, blood gas and acid-base values
help to establish the diagnosis. Treatment includes early mechanical ventilation and surfactant administration.
In this neonate, the history of prematurity, the classic presentation, and the characteristic chest-x ray make
HMD the most likely diagnosis.
(Choice A) Transient tachypnea usually follows an uneventful normal term vaginal delivery or cesarean
delivery. It is characterized by the early onset of tachypnea, sometimes with retractions or expiratory
grunting, and typically, cyanosis that is relieved by minimal oxygen. The lungs are usually clear without rales
or rhonchi, and the chest-x ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings, fluid lines in the fissures,
overaeration, a flat diaphragm, and occasionally, pleural fluid. Hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and acidosis are
uncommon. The distinguishing feature in this case is the x-ray finding.
(Choice C) Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) should be suspected in all term and
post-term infants with cyanosis with or without fetal distress. Persistence of the fetal circulatory pattern of
right-to-left shunting through the PDA and foramen ovale after birth is due to very high pulmonary vascular
resistance. The associated hypoxia is universal and unresponsive to 100% oxygen. The chest-x ray may be
normal or may show parenchymal opacification in the chest, depending on the etiology. Although the clinical
presentation of PPHN is indistinguishable from HMD, the x-ray findings of this case are very typical and
therefore very suggestive of the latter.
(Choice D) Meconium aspiration syndrome usually occurs in term or post-term infants. Either in utero or
more often with the first breath, thick and particulate meconium is aspirated into the lungs, resulting in small
airway obstruction and consequent respiratory distress that presents within the first hour of birth. Partial
obstruction of some airways may lead to pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum. Patchy infiltrates, coarse
streaking of both lung fields, increased anteroposterior diameter, and flattening of the diaphragm characterize
the typical chest-x ray.
(Choice E) Intracranial hemorrhage in neonates classically presents as periods of apnea, pallor or cyanosis,
poor suckling, abnormal eye signs, high-pitched, shrill cry, muscular twitching, convulsions, decreased
muscle tone or paralysis, metabolic acidosis, shock, and a decreased hematocrit. The fontanel may be
tense and bulging. The condition is rarely present at birth and is diagnosed on the basis of the history, clinical
manifestations, and trans-fontanel cranial ultrasonography or computed tomography (CT).
Educational Objective:
Hyaline membrane disease should be suspected in preterm infants with respiratory distress and hypoxia not
responding to oxygen therapy. The characteristic chest-x ray finding of HMD demonstrates fine reticular
granularity of the lung parenchyma, and treatment includes early mechanical ventilation and surfactant
administration.

question:
A 9-year-old girl is seen in the office for unsteady gait and weakness in the lower limbs. On examination she
is found to have a wide-based gait with constant shifting of position to maintain her balance. There is
decreased vibratory and position sense in the lower extremities, and ankle jerks are absent bilaterally. Her
feet are deformed with high plantar arches. MRI of the brain and spinal cord shows marked atrophy of the
cervical spinal cord and minimal cerebellar atrophy. Nerve conduction velocity results are within normal limits.
EKG shows T-wave inversions in the inferior and lateral chest leads. The mother says that her other child, a
3-year-old boy, is completely normal. He shares toys with his sister and plays well with other children at
playschool. He is able to copy squares and crosses but is unable to copy a triangle. Which of the following
statements would you advance while discussing the girl's condition with her mother?
options: A. There is nothing to worry about since it's a non-progressive condition
B. It is most likely a result of spontaneous mutation & the chances of your boy developing the same condition are minimal
C. The EKG abnormalities are most likely due to myocardial ischaemia
D. The inability of your boy to copy a triangle worries me since it may be an early manifestation of the same condition your daughter is suffering from
E. I advise you to go for prenatal counseling if you desire any future pregnancies
explanation:
The physical findings and MRI features described in the question classically fit into the description of
Friedreich Ataxia (FA). It is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by an excessive number of
trinucleotide repeat sequences, resulting in an abnormality of tocopherol transfer protein. The disorder is
progressive with poor prognosis (Choice A). Most patients are wheelchair bound by the age of 25 with death
occurring by 30-35 years of age.
FA is associated with necrosis and degeneration of cardiac muscle fibers leading to myocarditis, myocardial
fibrosis and cardiomyopathy. Cardiac arrhythmia and congestive heart failure contribute to a significant
number of deaths. T-wave inversion in this case is most likely due to myocarditis, and not myocardial
infarction (Choice C). [Remember the differential for T-wave inversion: myocardial infarction, myocarditis, old
pericarditis, myocardial contusion and digoxin toxicity].
The milestones of the 3-year-old boy are normal and ability to copy a triangle develops after the age of 5
years (Choice D). [3 years- copies a cross and circle, 4 years- copies a square and rectangle, 5 years-
copies a triangle, 6 years- copies a diamond]
In families with one affected child, the subsequent risk of another affected child is 25%, which is significant
(Choice B). Genetic counseling is recommended for prenatal diagnosis for parents with one affected child
(Choice E).
Educational Objective:
Friedreich Ataxia is an autosomal recessive condition and genetic counseling is recommended for prenatal
diagnosis for parents with one affected child.

question:
A 28-year-old Caucasian female comes to the office due to fever for the past 3 days. She also complains of
pain and swelling in her right breast for the past 4 days. She exclusively breastfeeds her 3-month-old baby.
On examination, she is febrile. Her right breast is engorged, red and tender, without any area of fluctuation.
She wants to know if she can continue to breastfeed. Which of the following is a contraindication to
breastfeeding?
options: E. Hemolytic disease of the newborn
explanation:
Although breastfeeding is generally encouraged due to its many advantages, physicians should always watch
out for situations in which breastfeeding may do more harm than good. Some contraindications to
breastfeeding include certain active maternal infections (i.e., HIV, tuberculosis, herpes simplex lesions on or
near the nipple, malaria, sepsis, typhoid fever), eclampsia, nephritis, substance abuse, and breast cancer.
Transmission of HIV by breastfeeding is well documented; therefore, the presence of maternal HIV infection is
an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding.
(Choice A) Mastitis is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Some physicians actually encourage
breastfeeding since this prevents engorgement, along with other subsequent symptoms such as fissures
and cracking of the nipple. The woman in this case most likely has mastitis.
(Choice C) Maternal rubella infection is not a contraindication to breastfeeding since there is currently
insufficient evidence regarding the associated risks.
(Choice D) Breast milk jaundice is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Mothers of such infants are
instructed to switch their babies to formula-feeding for 1-2 days. This allows the increased indirect bilirubin
levels of the infant to return to normal values. After 2 days, the mother resumes breastfeeding, and further
hyperbilirubinemia usually does not recur.
(Choice E) Hemolytic disease of the newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis) is not a contraindication to
breastfeeding because antibodies in the mother's milk are inactivated in the intestinal tract and do not
contribute to further hemolysis of the infant's RBCs.
Educational Objective:
Transmission of HIV by breastfeeding is well documented; therefore, the presence of maternal HIV infection is
an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding.

question:
A female infant develops cyanosis. She was delivery vaginally at 43 weeks' gestation, and the amniotic fluid
had a greenish color. She has dry, peeling skin, emaciated extremities and long fingernails. Tachypnea,
nasal flaring, and sub- and intercostal retractions are observed. Auscultation reveals rales and rhonchi. The
chest radiograph reveals flattening of the diaphragm, hyperinflation of the lungs, and patchy opacities diffusely
distributed over both lung fields. Arterial blood gases reveal hypoxia and hypercarbia. What is most likely
impairing the normal respiratory function of this newborn?
explanation:
The patient's history and physical findings are suggestive of meconium aspiration. The greenish amniotic
fluid indicates the presence of meconium. The condition is more common in post-mature and
small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants. The characteristic presentation includes signs of respiratory
distress (i.e., marked tachypnea and cyanosis at birth), rales, rhonchi, nasal flaring, grunting, and use of
accessory muscles of respiration (e.g., subcostal and/or intercostal retractions). Hyperinflation occurs
secondarily to the valve-like mechanism by which meconium obstructs the airways, keeping air from exiting
the lungs after each inspiration. This state of hyperinflation consequently leads to a barrel-shaped chest
(increased antero-posterior diameter). Hypoxia and acidosis also ensue, thus increasing pulmonary vascular
resistance and aggravating the respiratory compromise. The typical chest radiograph of meconium
aspiration (as seen in this patient) includes flattening of the diaphragm, hyperinflation, coarse streaking
and patchy opacities over both lung fields. Complications include pneumothorax, infection, pulmonary
hypertension, residual lung problems and permanent neurological impairment due to asphyxia.
(Choice A) Fetal lung fluid causes respiratory difficulty in transient tachypnea of the newborn. This condition
is characterized by lack of clearance of fetal lung fluid and occurs most commonly in fetuses delivered
by cesarean section. It is a self-limited condition that generally improves after a few hours. Auscultation
does not show rales or rhonchi. The lungs are usually very clear. Patients usually do not require more than
40% FiO2 to oxygenate adequately.
(Choice B) Poor alveolar compliance is characteristic of respiratory distress syndrome. It is secondary to
lack of pulmonary surfactant and occurs primarily in preterm infants. This patient is post-mature, based on
the gestational age, dry and peeling skin, emaciated extremities and long fingernails.
(Choice D) The flattening of this patient's diaphragm is due to hyperinflation (not paralysis) of the lungs.
Furthermore, the characteristic radiographic finding of diaphragmatic paralysis is an elevated
hemi-diaphragm.
Educational Objective:
Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs most commonly in low birthweight and post-mature infants. It is
characterized by respiratory distress at birth, rales, rhonchi, hyperinflation, and coarse streaking and patchy
opacities on chest x-ray.

question:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his 27-year-old white mother for the evaluation of recurrent bone
fractures. His first fracture was that of the femur, and occured when he was 6 months old. He had a fracture
of the wrist 4 months ago. His mother also has a history of multiple fractures since childhood. She lost all
her teeth at a very early age and is complaining of deafness. Her husband has a history of severe alcohol
abuse. On examination, both mother and son have blue sclerae. What is the most likely involved disease
process?
explanation:
The above child is most likely suffering from osteogenesis imperfecta, which is an inherited connective tissue
disorder caused by a mutation in the genes coding for type I collagen. Since type I collagen is an important
structural protein that is present in the skin, sclera, bone, tendon and ligament, patients with this disorder
present with multiple recurrent fractures, blue sclera, hearing loss, joint laxity, short stature, and scoliosis.
(Choice B) Marfan syndrome is one of the most common connective tissue disorders, and is caused by
mutation of the fibrillin-1 gene. Its mode of inheritance is autosomal dominant. The common features of this
disorder include skeletal manifestations (e.g., arachnodactyly, hypermobility of joints), ectopia lentis, and
aortic root dilatation.
(Choice C) Child abuse suspected in the presence of any of the following: retinal hemorrhages, burns,
bruising, fractures or abrasions. This is a good differential diagnosis for the given case; however,
the features of this patient (e.g., fractures, blue sclerae, family history of fractures and hearing loss) are very
typical of osteogenesis imperfecta.
(Choice D) Children with rickets have slow growth and skeletal deformities. Blue sclerae and hearing loss
are not the features of rickets.
(Choice E) Early manifestations of congenital syphilis include jaundice, rash, lymphadenopathy, rhinitis and
hepatosplenomegaly. Late manifestations occur around two year of age; these include saber shins, keratitis,
Hutchinson's teeth, saddle-nose deformity and deafness. The above child has typical features of
osteogenesis imperfecta, not congenital syphilis.
Educational Objective:
Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by mutations in type 1 collagen. Its typical features are blue sclera and
recurrent fractures.
*Extremely high yield question for USMLE step-1 and step-2

question:
A one-month-old infant is brought to the physician for evaluation. His mother reports that for the past two
weeks, he has been crying inconsolably for several hours every evening. His mother has tried multiple
methods to calm the infant down, but nothing seems to work. The infant was born full term without
complications. He takes two ounces of cow's milk-based formula every two hours and is growing well. His
mother reports that he is happy and alert the rest of the day. The child's physical examination is
unremarkable. Which of the following is a true statement about the child's condition?
options: A. The infant should be started on ranitidine for gastroesophageal reflux.
B. The infant should be changed to a lactose-free formula.
C. Bloody stools are often present.
D. The child will likely develop an anxiety disorder during childhood.
E. This condition usually resolves by four months of age.
explanation:
Infantile colic is defined as excessive crying in an otherwise healthy infant for more than three hours a day,
more than three days a week, and more than three weeks in a month. Colic usually presents within the first
three weeks of life and resolves spontaneously by four months of age. Most parents report that the crying
occurs at the same time of day, typically in the early evening. The crying begins suddenly, and the child
generally cannot be comforted. The cause of colic is not known. Some evidence suggests a digestive tract
origin (eg, trapped gas) leading to abdominal pain. Because the etiology of colic is not known, there is no
universally accepted treatment. Proposed treatments include soothing measures, simethicone (which
decreases the surface tension of gas bubbles), or probiotics.
(Choice A) Gastroesophageal reflux usually presents with excessive spitting up and crying related to
feedings. Medication is generally reserved for those infants not gaining weight appropriately.
(Choice B) Changing to a lactose-free formula is not useful in infants with colic.
(Choice C) Children with intussusception are usually 3-36 months in age. They have abdominal pain that
occurs at different times of the day and bloody ("currant jelly") stools.
(Choice D) There is no association between colic and anxiety disorders.
Educational objective:
Colic presents by three weeks of age with excessive crying for more than three hours a day, more than three
days a week, and more than three weeks a month, usually resolving by four months of age.

question:
An 18-month-old male is brought to the hospital because of fever, dyspnea, and productive cough of two days
duration. His mother reports that he just recovered from prolonged diarrhea due to Giardia infection. His past
medical history is also significant for pneumonia and recurrent ear infections since 6 months of age. On
physical examination, his temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 40/min.
Examination reveals a young child in mild respiratory distress and bronchial breath sounds in the right lower
lung lobe. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his recurrent infections?
explanation:
This infant has a history of Giardia and recurrent sinopulmonary infections since six months of age,
suggesting a genetic defect in B-lymphocyte maturation (Choice E). Genetic B-cell deficiencies present
after 6 months of age because this is when the newborn's levels of maternal antibodies drop. Affected
infants are predisposed to recurrent sinopulmonary infections with encapsulated organisms like H. influenzae
and S. pneumoniae because immune destruction of encapsulated organisms depends upon the humoral
immune response. Deficiency in IgA, which inhabits the GI tract, is the specific deficiency that predisposes to
Giardia infection.
(Choice A) Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a condition of impaired oxidative metabolism. In CGD,
a defect in the NADPH-oxidase system of phagocytic cells results in defective intracellular killing. Patients
are therefore prone to abscesses secondary to catalase-producing organisms like Aspergillus and
Staphylococcus.
(Choice B) Gonococcal and meningococcal infections are common in patients with complement
deficiency. S. pneumoniae and H. influenzae infections do occur in this patient population as well, but
infections with Giardia are not typically seen.
(Choice C) Thymic hypoplasia is one element of DiGeorge syndrome. The resultant T-cell deficiency puts
patients at high risk for viral and fungal infections.
(Choice D) Adenosine deaminase deficiency is commonly the genetic defect underlying severe combined
immunodeficiency (SCID). Patients with SCID have a deficiency of both B- and T-cells. The T-cell deficiency
predisposes to viral and fungal infections and the B-cell deficiency predisposes to infection by bacteria.
Educational objective:
Patients with genetic B-cell deficiencies begin to develop recurrent infections after passing 6 months of
age. The deficient humoral immune response in these patients impairs the body's ability to destroy
encapsulated organisms. Hence, recurrent sinopulmonary infections with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae
are common. Lack of IgA also predisposes to Giardia infection.

question:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the office due to seizures that occurred 2 hours ago. This is her first episode.
Her parents are also concerned because she is not able to carry on activities that children of her age are
expected to do. On examination, there is a red flat lesion covering the left eye area and adjacent facial skin,
which does not blanch on pressure, and which the parents say has been present since birth. Other pertinent
findings are hemianopia, hemiparesis, and hemisensory disturbances. An x-ray of the skull shows tramline
intra-cranial calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The presentation of Sturge-Weber syndrome can include focal or generalized seizures, mental retardation,
and a port wine stain or nevus flammeus along the territory of the trigeminal nerve, which represents a
congenital unilateral cavernous hemangioma. Seizures are the usual neurological presentation and may start
at any age. Other pertinent findings are hemianopia, hemiparesis, hemisensory disturbance, and ipsilateral
glaucoma. Skull x-rays, taken after the age of 2 years, reveal gyriform intracranial calcifications that
resemble a tramline. Treatment is aimed at controlling the seizures and reducing intraocular
pressure. Argon laser therapy is successful in removing the skin lesions.
(Choice B) The initial presentation in tuberous sclerosis is also a seizure, but the cutaneous abnormality is
called adenoma sebaceum, which appears between 5-10 years of age.
(Choice C) Capillary hemangioma usually presents at birth or appears by 6 months of age. It consists of
small capillaries and presents as an irregular, raised lesion that blanches on pressure. Approximately 75%
regress by age 7.
(Choice D) Epilepsy is difficult to diagnose with just a single episode of seizures.
(Choice E) The cutaneous lesions of neurofibromatosis are axillary freckling and café-au-lait spots. The
neurological presentation is dependent on the location and growth of the tumors.
Educational Objective:
Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome that is characterized by a congenital unilateral
cavernous hemangioma along the trigeminal nerve distribution and radiographic evidence of intra-cranial
calcifications that resemble a tramline.

question:
A 10-day-old infant is brought to the office by her mother for the evaluation of purulent discharge from both
eyes. The discharge appeared three days ago, after which the child developed a cough. On examination, the
infant's eyes appear normal, except for the presence of purulent discharge. Auscultation reveals diffuse rales
without wheezing. Chest radiograph shows a hyperinflated thorax. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This newborn most likely has conjunctival and pulmonary chlamydial infection. Chlamydia is usually
transmitted from the mother to the neonate during passage through the birth canal. Infected infants have a
25% to 50% risk of developing conjunctivitis, and a 5% to 20% risk of developing pneumonia. Chlamydia is
the most common causative agent of infectious neonatal conjunctivitis. Chlamydial conjunctivitis develops a
few days to several weeks after birth, and manifests with conjunctival congestion, edema, and mucoid or
frank purulent discharge. Pneumonia usually appears 3 to 19 weeks after birth, and symptoms include
cough, tachypnea, and rales; there is no fever, and wheezing is rare. (The latter two features permit to
differentiate chlamydial pneumonia from RSV bronchiolitis.) The treatment is oral erythromycin for 14 days,
as topical agents are ineffective.
Aside from an increased incidence of neonatal conjunctivitis and pneumonia, cervical carriage of
Chlamydia has been associated with a higher incidence of preterm labor, PROM, and late post-term
endometritis. All these adverse outcomes and neonatal disease is best prevented by early detection and
treatment. Screening is thus recommended in high-risk individuals such as single mothers, adolescents,
patients with low socioeconomic status, and promiscuous patients. Erythromycin is the drug of choice in
pregnancy and should be given to both the patient and her sexual partner. Another test should be performed
later in pregnancy, and a positive result warrants a second course of antibiotics.
(Choice A) Gonococcal conjunctivitis is extremely purulent and presents between the 2nd and 5th day after
birth.
(Choice B) Chemical conjunctivitis is secondary to the administration of prophylactic drops of silver
nitrate. The conjunctivitis is mild and resolves within 24 hours without treatment.
(Choice D) Ocular disease of congenital rubella syndrome is more serious and may include microphthalmia,
cataract, glaucoma and retinopathy.
(Choice E) The discharge in adenovirus conjunctivitis is also accompanied with respiratory symptoms but of
the upper respiratory tract. Moreover, the discharge is usually serous rather than mucoid or purulent, and is
associated with mild itching.
Educational Objective:
Chlamydia is the most common causative agent of infectious neonatal conjunctivitis. Chlamydial pneumonia
can develop in infected infants.

question:
An 11-month-old girl is brought by her mother to the office due to fever, fussiness, and irritability. The girl has
a tendency to hold and pull on her left ear. For the past few days, she has had rhinorrhea and nasal
congestion. Her medical history reveals nothing particular. Her temperature is 38.9C (102F). Otoscopic
examination reveals a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with decreased mobility on air
compression. What is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition?
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation points to the diagnosis of acute otitis media. The most common causative
organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae (40% of cases), followed by non-typable Haemophilus influenzae (25-
30%), and Moraxella catarrhalis (10-15%). Approximately 30% of cases are caused by viruses,
especially respiratory syncytial virus and rhinovirus. Approximately 5% of cases are caused by other bacteria
(e.g., Group A streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa). The risk factors of
otitis media include age (6-36 months), low socioeconomic status, use of formula milk, caretaker smoking,
respiratory allergy, craniofacial anomalies, and chronic middle ear effusion. The complications are
numerous, and include chronic suppurative otitis media, acute mastoiditis, labyrinthitis, facial paralysis,
cholesteatoma, tympanosclerosis, perforation, conductive hearing loss, and permanent sensorineural
hearing loss. The first-line treatment is a ten-day course of amoxicillin. If this regimen fails, amoxicillin-
clavulanic acid, cefuroxime axetil, and IM ceftriaxone are good alternatives.
(Choice A) Haemophilus influenza is found in 25-30% of cases, and is the second most common pathogen.
(Choice C) Moraxella catarrhalis is the third most common causative organism of acute otitis media (found
in 10-15% of cases).
(Choice D and F) S. aureus and gram-negative organisms are found most commonly in neonates and very
young infants who are hospitalized.
(Choice E) Group A Streptococcus, S. aureus and gram-negative bacteria are responsible for 5% of cases
of otitis media.
(Choice G and H) Rhinovirus and respiratory syncytial virus are the most common respiratory viruses found
in middle ear exudates of children with otitis media; however, these viruses are rarely isolated, and are most
commonly found in association with bacteria.
Educational Objective:
The most common causative organism of acute otitis media is Streptococcus pneumoniae (40% of cases),
followed by non-typable Haemophilus influenzae (25-30%), and Moraxella catarrhalis (10-15%). The first-line
treatment is a ten-day course of amoxicillin

question:
A newborn is noted to have jaundice, a large tongue, hoarse cry and decreased activity. Neonatal screening
is performed, and the infant is subsequently diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism. What is the most
likely cause of congenital hypothyroidism in the United States?
options: C. Thyroid peroxidase defects of organification and coupling
D. Radioiodine administration in mother during pregnancy
explanation:
Thyroid dysgenesis (i.e, aplasia, hypoplasia, or an ectopic gland) is the most common cause of congenital
hypothyroidism, accounting for 85% of cases in USA.
(Choice B) A variety of defects in the biosynthesis of thyroid hormone may result in congenital
hypothyroidism, but this is not the commonest cause. Such conditions are characterized by a goiter (almost
always present) and an autosomal recessive mode of transmission.
(Choice C) Defects in thyroid peroxidase can cause defective organification and coupling, leading to hypothyroidism, but this is less common than dysgenesis.
(Choice D) Hypothyroidism has been reported as a result of inadvertent administration of radioiodine during
pregnancy for treatment of maternal Grave's disease or cancer of the thyroid, but it is not the most common
cause of congenital hypothyroidism. In a woman of childbearing age, a pregnancy test must be performed
before a therapeutic dose of 131I is given. 131I is also contraindicated in lactating mothers.
(Choice E) Deficiency of TSH and hypothyroidism may occur in any of the conditions associated with
developmental defects of the pituitary or hypothalamus; however, thyroid dysgenesis is still the most
common cause.
(Choice F) Iodine deficiency or endemic goiter is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism
worldwide, but is essentially not seen in the United States.
Educational Objective:
Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in United States.

question:
A 2 and a half-year-old child is brought to the office for the evaluation of easy bruising, nosebleeds, and
decreased activity over the past week. He had an upper respiratory infection that was treated with an
antibiotic 2 weeks ago. On examination, he is well-developed, seems well-nourished, anicteric, and pale.
Pertinent findings include some small palpable posterior cervical lymph nodes, sinus tachycardia, a grade I/VI
systolic ejection murmur, ecchymoses on his left shoulder and both lower extremities, and petechiae over his
extremities and groin. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. The laboratory findings are as follows:
Hemoglobin                 7.9 g/dL
Hematocrit                   24%
Platelet count               12,000/mm3
WBC                         3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count         0.5%
A bone marrow biopsy reveal a markedly hypocellular marrow with decreased megakaryocytes and
precursors of the erythroid and myeloid cell lines. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Acquired aplastic anemia results from an injury to the bone marrow by radiation, drugs (chemotherapy or
antibiotics such as chloramphenicol), insecticides, toxins (benzene, carbon tetrachloride), or
infections. Signs and symptoms include pallor, fatigue, weakness, loss of appetite, easy bruising, petechiae,
mucosal hemorrhage, and fever. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates a normocytic or macrocytic anemia,
leukopenia, reticulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy is essential to make the
diagnosis; it typically shows profound hypocellularity with a decrease in all cell lines and fatty infiltration of the
marrow.
(Choice B) Classically, patients with Fanconi's anemia have pancytopenia and characteristic congenital
anomalies, such as hyperpigmentation on the trunk, neck and intertriginous areas and/or cafe-au-lait spots,
short stature, upper limb abnormalities, hypogonadism, skeletal anomalies, eye or eyelid changes, and renal
malformations. Blood counts start to decrease between 4 and 12 years of age, and the initial manifestation
is usually thrombocytopenia, followed by neutropenia, then anemia.
(Choice C) Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA), or congenital pure red cell aplasia, presents in the first 3
months of life with pallor and poor feeding. CBC reveals a normocytic or macrocytic anemia with
reticulocytopenia. WBC and platelet counts are normal.
(Choice D) Transient erythroblastopenia of childhood (TEC) is an acquired red cell aplasia which occurs in
healthy children between 6 months and 5 years old. There is a gradual onset of symptoms such as pallor
and decreased activity. The physical examination is unremarkable except for pallor and tachycardia. The
typical laboratory findings are normocytic normochromic anemia, with hemoglobin levels ranging from 3 to 8
g/dL, and an extremely low reticulocyte count.
(Choice E) Bone marrow infiltration due to leukemia results in pancytopenia by crowding out the normal bone
marrow elements. Patients present with lethargy (from anemia), bruising and bleeding (from
thrombocytopenia), and unexplained fever. They may also complain of bone pain or present with a
limp. CBC shows pancytopenia or anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis. Acute myeloid leukemia is
more common in adults. In this case, the classic presentation after an upper respiratory infection, as well
as the absence of other features of leukemia (normal bone marrow), makes acquired aplastic anemia the
best answer.
Educational Objective:
Aplastic anemia should be suspected in any patient with pancytopenia following drug intake, exposure to
toxins or viral infections.

question:
A 6-year-old African-American boy is brought to the office by his mother due to a painful right knee, fever and
chills over the last 2 days. The child was diagnosed with pharyngitis 2 weeks ago, and was treated with a
10-day course of penicillin G. His temperature is 38.8C(102F) and pulse rate is 102/min. On examination,
his right knee joint is swollen and erythematous, with a decreased range of motion. The laboratory findings
are significant for leukocytosis and an elevated ESR. X-rays of both the right hip and knee joints are normal.
What is the most appropriate treatment for the patient's condition?
options: A. Bed rest with the right knee joint in a position of comfort
B. Repeat a ten-day course of penicillin G
C. Bed rest & a ten-day course of penicillin G
E. Right knee arthrocentesis & intravenous nafcillin
explanation:
This child has features suggestive of septic arthritis. Septic arthritis can occur following skin or upper
respiratory tract infections. Arthrocentesis is both diagnostic and therapeutic, and is mandatory in all
suspected cases. Blood cultures and synovial fluid cultures must be obtained prior to administering the
antibiotics. Empiric antibiotic therapy (IV nafcillin or IV cefazolin) should be started with pending synovial fluid
cultures.
(Choice A) Bed rest for 7 days with the knee joint in a position of comfort is the treatment for transient
synovitis, not septic arthritis.
(Choices B and C) The patient has received an adequate course of penicillin for pharyngitis; therefore,
repeating the course is not required. Moreover, penicillin G is not the drug of choice for the empiric treatment
of septic arthritis. The most common cause of septic arthritis in a native joint is Staphylococcus
aureus. Almost 99% of the staphylococcus strains are resistant to penicillin. The commonly used empirical
antibiotics are nafcillin or cefazolin. Vancomycin should be used if the suspicion for methicillin resistant
staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is high.
(Choice D) Aspirin is not usually used in children because of the risk of Reye's syndrome.
Educational Objective:
Arthrocentesis followed by empiric treatment with intravenous nafcillin are the most appropriate measures for
the management of suspected septic arthritis in a child.

question:
A 6-year-old Caucasian boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother with hemiplegia of acute onset.
She states that she found the boy unconscious in his room where she had left him playing several minutes
ago; and, he slowly gained consciousness, but could not move his right arm and leg. His past medical history
is insignificant. Physical examination reveals right hemiparesis with little sensory abnormalities. No meningeal
signs are present. The motor function restored spontaneously during 24-hour observation in the hospital. A
CT scan of the head is normal. What is the most probable cause of this patient's problem?
explanation:
The clinical scenario described is suggestive of Todd's paralysis as the cause of this patient's hemiparesis.
Sudden loss of consciousness with following disorientation and slow gain of consciousness is a
characteristic description of a seizure, if the convulsive episode was missed. Postictal paralysis (Todd
paralysis) may follow generalized as well as focal seizures. The exact pathophysiology of this condition is not
well understood, but most probably involves alteration in neuronal electrical activity. The motor deficit usually
improves rapidly with restoration of the function within 24 hours. Todd's paralysis usually indicates that a
structural abnormality underlying the seizure is present.
Relation of the hemiparesis to the seizure-like episode and rapid reversibility of the motor deficit makes the
other causes, like vascular thrombosis (Choices A, B, and C) or embolism (Choice K) unlikely.
Migraine (Choice I) can produce reversible paralysis, but a history of headaches is typical.
Internal carotid artery dissection (Choice L) is related to a specific trauma and usually manifests as a
persistent neurologic defect.
Educational Objective:
Todd's paralysis represents a postictal condition that usually rapidly improves with restoration of motor
function within 24 hours.

question:
A 6-year-old female with Down syndrome is brought to the physician for behavioral changes. Over the past
few weeks, she has begun refusing to do her usual activities. Her parents also report that she seems dizzy
and state that she has developed urinary incontinence. On examination, she is hypotonic but hyperreflexic
with a positive Babinski reflex. Her gait is ataxic. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Atlantoaxial instability is a malformation seen in 10-15% of patients with Down syndrome, and most
commonly occurs due to excessive laxity in the posterior transverse ligament, which causes increased
mobility between the atlas (C1) and the axis (C2). Fortunately, only 1-2% of Down syndrome patients with
atlantoaxial instability are symptomatic. Symptoms usually progress over several weeks and result from
compression of the spinal cord. Presenting symptoms include behavioral changes, torticollis, urinary
incontinence, and vertebrobasilar symptoms such as dizziness, vertigo, and diplopia. On examination, upper
motor neuron symptoms such as leg spasticity, hyperreflexia, a positive Babinski sign, and clonus are often
present. Patients with Down syndrome are normally hypotonic, and they may remain hypotonic or have
increased tone with symptomatic atlantoaxial instability.
Atlantoaxial instability is suspected on physical examination and diagnosed with lateral radiographs of the
cervical spine in flexion, extension, and in a neutral position. Open mouth radiographs can also be helpful in
visualizing the odontoid. Treatment consists of surgical fusion of the first cervical vertebrae (C1) to the
second (C2).
(Choice A) Although there is a higher prevalence of Alzheimer disease among individuals with Down
syndrome, it usually presents around ages 40-50.
(Choice C) The risk of hypothyroidism is increased in individuals with Down syndrome. These patients
present with decreased growth velocity, weight gain, cold intolerance, fatigue, constipation, or declining
school performance. Neurologic symptoms can include delayed reflexes, but upper motor neuron signs
should not be present.
(Choice D) Mental retardation is seen in individuals with Down syndrome and can vary in its
severity. However, progressive neurologic symptoms are not seen with mental retardation alone.
(Choice E) Spinal cord infarction presents with the acute onset of severe pain, weakness, and
paresthesias. This condition is rare and more commonly seen in adults, and there is no increased risk in
patients with Down syndrome.
Educational objective:
Atlantoaxial instability should be suspected in any patient with Down syndrome who presents with upper
motor neuron findings.

question:
A 6-month-old Hispanic boy is brought to the office for a well-baby check-up and follow-up immunizations.
His mother denies any new complaints. Physical examination reveals lesions that do not fade into the
surrounding skin, shown in picture below.
[Image showing Mongolian spot was referenced here but not provided in text]
What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: A. Perform fundoscopy to rule out retinal hemorrhages
B. Coagulation tests to rule out a coagulopathy
C. Immediately report to the authorities for child abuse
D. Do nothing, since it is likely that these lesions will disappear in the next few years
E. Schedule for excisional therapy with laser
explanation:
This baby has a classic Mongolian spot, which is common among dark-skinned races. The cause is
entrapment of the melanocytes in the dermis during their migration from the neural crest into the epidermis in
fetal development. The lesion is a blue, bluish-gray, bluish-green or blue-black, flat skin marking that usually
appears at birth. It is mostly located at the base of the spine, on the lower back, and on the buttocks,
although it can also be seen in other parts of the body such as the shoulders, arms, wrists, legs, ankles or
abdomen. The face, palms and soles are usually spared. The bluish discoloration usually fades after a few
years and almost always disappears within or after seven years. Most cases do not require any treatment.
(Choices A and C) Retinal hemorrhages are common findings in child abuse. Multiple retinal hemorrhages
that differ in size and color support the suspicion of child abuse. A precipitating factor (stepfather/mother,
financial issue) is usually present in the history. In addition, there may be bruises that usually have
associated swelling and tenderness. In this case, nothing in the history and physical findings is suggestive
of child abuse; therefore, reporting to the authorities is not necessary.
(Choice B) Even though bruises secondary to coagulation disorders are plausible, the characteristic location
and size of this patient's lesions make coagulation tests unnecessary.
(Choice E) Excisional therapy with laser is not necessary since Mongolian spots are usually self-limited
lesions. It is usually indicated for giant cavernous hemangioma.
Educational Objective:
Mongolian spots are most commonly found in dark-skinned populations, present at birth, and usually fade or
disappear in several years.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because he is lethargic and not as active as the other
kids on their block. He has difficulty walking and getting up, and he always appears tired. His mother thinks
that she has a relative with a disorder that causes weakness. On examination, the child is alert but quiet. His
calves appear hypertrophied. His reflexes are depressed. When he gets up from the floor, he uses his
hands to climb on his legs to assume an upright position. What is the most likely diagnosis of this child?
explanation:
This boy presents with proximal muscle weakness, pseudohypertrophied calf muscles, decreased
reflexes, and a positive Gower's sign (uses hands to walk up the legs and assume an upright position). His
features are very characteristic of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Other features include obesity, mental
retardation and cardiomyopathy. Dystrophin is usually absent. EMG shows myopathic pattern. Serum CK
levels are very high (4000-5000 IU). The diagnosis is confirmed by muscle biopsy and family pedigree
analysis. The current treatment is supportive, although gene therapy trials are underway. The prognosis is
poor, with most patients wheelchair-bound by 12 years of age.
(Choice A) Myasthenia gravis symptoms may fluctuate, and may be purely ocular or
generalized. Symptoms may include diplopia, ptosis, and muscle fatigue with normal deep tendon
reflexes. Ten to fifteen percent of patients have a thymoma; hence, a CT scan is done to check for a
thymoma. The diagnosis is confirmed by a positive edrophonium test (temporary improvement after the
administration of edrophonium).
(Choice B) Dermatomyositis has a gradual onset in adult life, and is more common in females. Skin
changes may precede or follow muscle findings. There may be a rash on the eyelids, nose, cheeks, trunk
and extremities. There may be an associated vasculitis in 25% of cases. Muscle biopsy is diagnostic.
(Choice D) Polio may be a subclinical or a mild abortive illness. The individual may have a non-specific
febrile illness. Some individuals may have flaccid paralysis, absent deep tendon reflexes and normal
sensation. There is no hypertrophy of the muscles. Approximately 10-25% may recover for up to 6
months. The illness is prevented by the polio vaccine, and is almost eradicated in the USA.
(Choice E) Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder and is a major cause of mental retardation
in males. The typical features include facial overgrowth and macroorchidism. Patients may also be
hyperactive or autistic. Patients do not have any muscular deficits.
Educational Objective:
Suspect Duchenne muscular dystrophy in a child with proximal muscle weakness, positive Gower's sign,
depressed reflexes, and pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles. Dystrophin is usually absent. EMG shows
myopathic pattern. Serum CK levels are very high (4000-5000 IU). The diagnosis is confirmed by muscle
biopsy.

question:
A 2-month-old male infant is rushed to the emergency department by his baby sitter. She says that the baby
became unresponsive and blue while feeding. The whole episode lasted 45-60 seconds, but the baby still
appears pale. She denies any history of coughing or choking. On examination, the infant appears cyanotic
and tachypneic. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg; his pulse rate is 155/min and regular. On
auscultation, a harsh pansystolic murmur is noted at the left sternal border, along with a single S2.
Hepatomegaly is noted. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 80%. Based on this history and
physical examination, what is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic congenital disease in children less than 4 years of
age. Patients often present with cyanotic spells. The classic tetrad includes (1) overriding aorta, (2) right
ventricular hypertrophy, (3) subpulmonary stenosis (single S2), and (4) ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(pansystolic murmur). Because a large unrestrictive VSD is always present, the right ventricular pressure is
the same as the left ventricular and aortic pressures. Pulmonary artery pressure and flow are inversely
proportional to the degree of subpulmonary obstruction. The degree of cyanosis correlates precisely with the
amount of obstruction.
(Choices B and D) Patent ductus arteriosus and VSD are non-cyanotic congenital heart diseases.
(Choice E) Transposition of the great vessels is a common cause of death within the 1st year of
life. Children with this condition develop cyanosis and tachypnea within the first few days of life.
(Choice F) Hypoplastic left heart syndrome usually presents with heart failure in the first few weeks of life,
and carries a grave prognosis.
Educational Objective:
Tetralogy of Fallot, the most common cyanotic congenital disease in children less than 4 years of age,
presents with cyanotic spells and pansystolic murmur on examination.

question:
A 4-year-old Hispanic boy is brought to the office by his parents because he has difficulty in walking. The
child started walking at the age of 17 months. He often falls during walking and has a tendency to run on his
toes. He has relatives with a similar symptomatology and a maternal uncle who "had a premature death”.
Examination reveals weakened hip muscles, hypertrophied calves with wooden consistency, and positive
Gower's sign. What is the best test to confirm this patient's diagnosis?
explanation:
The patient most likely has Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), which is the most common muscular
dystrophy. His manifestations (i.e. pseudohypertrophy of the calves and positive Gower's sign) are
characteristic for the disease. Furthermore, the similar symptomatology in the maternal uncle points out an
X-linked recessive transmission. Muscle biopsy can confirm the diagnosis in this patient,
although performing genetic studies are currently the most appropriate way of confirming the diagnosis in
atypical cases.
(Choice A) An elevated serum creatinine kinase level is probably the earliest manifestation of the disease.
Increased levels can be seen in newborns. Similarly, aldolase levels are elevated, however, these levels can
drop as more muscle gets replaced with fat and fibrosis. These tests are typically used for screening
purposes, rather than confirmatory.
(Choices B and D) In DMD, EMG demonstrates a characteristic myopathic pattern with normal nerve
conduction velocities; however, it is not used to confirm the diagnosis.
Educational Objective:
Serum CK levels are used for screening the muscular dystrophies. Muscle biopsy can confirm the diagnosis
in most cases. The gold standard is genetic studies, which is required in atypical cases.

question:
A 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) by the paramedics due to nausea, vomiting,
diarrhea and abdominal pain over the past haur. His mother found an open multivitamin supplement battle
and some pills scattered on the kitchen floor. After his admission to the ED, he starts hyperventilating and
experiences hematemesis. His blood pressure is 30/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 50/min and
temperature is 37.2 C (98F). Abdominal plain x-ray reveals several small opacities in the stomach and
duodenum. Lab results are:
Hb                      13.5 g/dL
Ht                        42%
WBC                     10,000/cmm
Flatelets                 300,000/cmm
Blood Glucose          118 mg/dL
Serum Na               135 mEg/L
Serum K               3.4 mEq/L
Chloride                102 mEg/L
Bicarbonate             16 mEq/L
BUN                    16 mg/dL
Serum Creatinine       1.0 mg/dL
pH                        7.30
PaO2                    90 mm Hg
PaCO2                  29 mm Hg
What is the mast likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Iron also accumulates in the mitochondria and tissue, thus impairing energy production and
resulting in cellular damage and systemic toxicity. Hypotension then occurs due to the increased capillary
permeability and venodilation. The resulting peripheral hypoperfusion and mitochondrial damage lead to
accumulation of lactic and citric acid, and consequent metabolic acidosis. The other complications include
liver necrosis, coagulopathy, drowsiness, seizures and coma. Long-term sequelae include gastric scarring
and pyloric stenosis. Since iron is radio-opaque, the tablets can be seen in the stomach on abdominal x-ray.
The diagnasis is confirmed by measuring serum iron levels. The treatment depends on the severity of the
poisoning. Ipecac syrup to induce emesis is used in asymptomatic patients with an intact gag reflex.
Intravenous deferoxamine, an iron chelator, is used in moderate to severe cases of intoxication. Activated
charcoal is not effective, and gastric lavage is not recommended in young children.
(Choice A) There are no known cases of riboflavin (vitamin B2) poisoning.
(Choice B) Acute ingestion of vitamin A causes anorexia, bulging fontanelle (pseudotumar cerebri),
hyperirritability and vomiting.
(Choice C) Acute vitamin D ingestion causes anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, polyuria and
polydipsia.
(Choice D) Vitamin K may cause hyperbilirubinemia in premature infants.
(Choice F) Acute lead poisoning presents as vomiting, ataxia, colicky abdominal pain, irritability, seizures,
encephalopathy and cerebral edema.
(Choice G) Dimercaprol is the antidote for lead poisoning, as well as poisoning from other heavy metals
(e.g., gold, arsenic, mercury).
(Choice H) Aspirin poisoning is characterized by lethargy, fever, hyperpnea, vomiting, tinnitus and metabolic
acidosis. In addition, abdominal radiographs are usually unremarkable with this condition.
Educational Objective:
Iron poisoning presents as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding and
metabolic acidosis. Since iron is radio-opaque, the tablets can be seen in the stomach on abdominal x-ray.
The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring serum iron levels. Intravenous deferoxamine, an iron chelator, is
used in moderate to severe cases of intoxication.

question:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because he has been having painless passage of black
stools for the past few days. Otherwise, his bowel habits are normal. He has no other medical problems.
He takes no medication. His vital signs are within normal limits. The physical examination is unremarkable.
What is the mast likely diagnosis of this patient?
explanation:
Meckel's diverticulum typically presents with painless melena in 2 to 3-year-old children. It is present in 2-3%
