nasal polyps. In a young child with the above symptoms, it is essential to rule out cystic fibrosis. Cystic
fibrosis can present with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, bronchiectasis and failure to thrive. A
positive sweat test for sodium and chloride is diagnostic.
(Choice A) Leukemic patients can present with numerous infections, diarrhea and failure to thrive, although
such patients present with more serious bacterial and fungal infections. Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
may be found. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia and anemia. Other findings may
include hyperuricemia, hyponatremia, elevated LDH and hypokalemia.
(Choice C) Foreign bodies are a common cause of stridor or bronchial asthma; however, the onset of
respiratory symptoms is usually rapid, and there may not be an elevated WBC. Chest x-ray bronchoscopy
and endoscopy may be required for diagnosis. If the foreign body remains undetected, there may be a
persistent pneumonia, atelectasis or pneumothorax.
(Choice D) Nasal septal deviation may be developmental or traumatic. Individuals may present with
unilateral nasal obstruction, facial pain, and anosmia, or they may be asymptomatic. For asymptomatic
individuals, no treatment is required. Nasal septal deviation does not lead to recurrent upper respiratory tract
infections.
(Choice E) Allergic rhinitis is characterized by an immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated hypersensitivity to foreign
allergens. It may be acute or chronic, and can be confused with recurrent colds. It may present with itchy
eyes and tearing, swollen mucosa, headaches and nasal obstruction, if the age of onset is in the second
decade of life. Diagnosis is by allergy testing and findings of eosinophilia in the nasal discharge.
Educational Objective:
In a young child with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections and bilateral nasal polyps, cystic fibrosis
must be ruled out.

question:
A previously heathy 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) due to stridor of sudden
onset. Last night, he suddenly developed a high fever followed by breathing difficulty. His temperature is
40C(104F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 40/min. In the ED, the child is toxic-appearing, sitting up,
leaning forward and drooling. His lungs are clear, and oxygen saturation is 85% in room air. What is the
most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. Admit the patient and start him on broad spectrum antibiotics
B. Start the patient on intravenous methylprednisolone
C. Endotracheal intubation with a set-up for tracheostomy
D. Admit the patient and start him on nebulized racemic epinephrine
E. Start the patient on oral dexamethasone
F. Obtain a lateral neck x-ray
explanation:
Always think of epiglottitis first in a 3- to 7-year old child with acute respiratory distress, toxic appearance (i.e,
sitting up, leaning forward, drooling), stridor and high-grade fever. Tachycardia and tachypnea are also
present. This is a pediatric emergency and should be managed emergently with endotracheal intubation;
however, since intubation of such patients is difficult, preparation for possible tracheostomy is also standardly
performed. The complications of epiglottitis are serious, and include sudden airway obstruction.
In the pre vaccination era almost all the cases were due to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). Because of
the routine infant vaccination with Hib conjugate vaccines, the antimicrobial spectrum has changed. H.
influenzae type A and nontypable strains, H. parainfluenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus
aureus, and beta-hemolytic streptococci are commonly isolated in Hib vaccinated patients.
(Choice A) Airway management is the most important consideration in a patient with epiglottitis. Once the
airway is secure, IV antibiotic therapy with either ceftriaxone or cefotaxime should be initiated. Starting
antibiotics is not the first step in managing this patient.
(Choice D) Nebulized racemic epinephrine is used in the management of croup.
(Choice F) The three characteristic findings of epiglottitis in the lateral neck x-ray are: swollen epiglottis
(thumb sign), thickened aryepiglottic folds, and obliteration of the vallecula; however, one should not wait
for x-ray results when the child has the above mentioned presentation. (The child could die from acute
airway obstruction while he is getting the x-ray!)
Educational Objective:
Epiglottitis is a pediatric emergency. Secure the airway as soon as possible with endotracheal intubation and
set-up for possible tracheostomy. Visualization of the epiglottis should not be attempted.

question:
A 2-week-old baby girl is brought to the clinic for the evaluation of vaginal discharge. Her mother has noticed
a cloudy white vaginal discharge mixed with blood since yesterday. She was born by normal vaginal delivery
at term, and no congenital anomalies were noted at birth. Physical examination reveals a blood-stained,
odorless vaginal discharge. Her vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate next step in the
management of this patient?
explanation:
Female infants less than 3 months of age sometimes develop vaginal spotting or bleeding. Maternal
estrogens can cross the placenta and enter the fetal blood stream before birth, thereby causing a pubertal
effect in the newborn which disappears as soon as the hormone is cleared from the infant's circulation.
(Choice A) Chlamydial infection in the newborn occurs through transmission from the genital tract of infected
mothers. Infected infants may present with pneumonia and conjunctivitis. Vaginal discharge is not a feature
of chlamydial infection in the newborn.
(Choice B) Most herpes infections in the newborn are caused by HSV-2. Infection occurs while the infant
passes through the infected birth canal during delivery. This presents as a disseminated form of
infection, localized central nervous system disease or localized infection of the skin, eyes and mouth.
(Choice C) Vaginal cancer usually occurs in women over the age of 50, with the exception of women who
were exposed in utero to diethylstilbestrol. In this group of women, vaginal cancer occurs at an earlier age
(i.e., under the age of 30), but still not in the neonatal period.
(Choice E) Trichomonas infection is a sexually transmitted disease that is common in adolescents and in
sexually active males and females.
(Choice F) This child's discharge is physiological. There is no odor or discoloration. There is no reason to
suspect abuse in this child.
Educational Objective:
Vaginal discharge in the newborn is due to the effects of maternal estrogens. In such cases, reassurance of
the mother is all that is required.

question:
A 8-month-old male infant is brought to the physician's office by his mother due to failure to thrive. According
to the mother, the child always regurgitates shortly after feedings, and has even had a few episodes of
blood-stained projectile vomiting. During the vomiting episodes, the child tilts his head to the left and arches
his back. On examination, the child is afebrile. His abdomen is soft and non-tender to palpation. Laboratory
evaluation shows hypochromic microcytic anemia. What is the most appropriate test to confirm the most
likely diagnosis of this child?
options: E. Technetium (Tc) sulfur colloid gastroesophageal scan
explanation:
The child in this case most likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease, which is characterized
by regurgitation after feeding and failure to thrive. The position that the child assumes (i.e. tilted head and
arched back) is called "posturing of Sandifer's syndrome" and is the mechanism by which the child protects
his airways and reacts to the pain of the acid reflux. 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring study is the gold
standard for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal disease.
(Choices C, D and E) Although esophageal manometry, barium swallow and Technetium (Tc) sulfur colloid
gastroesophageal scan are useful in the evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease, these are not
confirmatory.
(Choice A) Chest x-rays may help in the detection of aspiration pneumonia, which is a possible complication
of gastroesophageal reflux disease, but these do not confirm the diagnosis.
Educational Objective:
24-hour esophageal pH monitoring is the gold standard for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

question:
A 15-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to vomiting and
bloodstained stools since yesterday. The vomitus is green. Recently, the neonate has been feeding poorly.
His birth history is not significant: he was absolutely normal and passed meconium within the first 12 hours of
life. He has been breastfed since birth. His pulse rate is 122/min and blood pressure is 80/50mm Hg. He is
irritable, his mucous membranes are dry, and his abdomen is distended. Based on these findings, what is
the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Midgut volvulus usually presents in a child less than one month old with bilious vomiting,
abdominal distension and passage of bloodstained stools. Volvulus is associated with malrotation of the gut,
and can be complicated by perforation and peritonitis.
(Choice A) Pyloric stenosis is a common congenital abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract. It usually
presents in a 4-8 week old infant as non-bilious projectile vomiting which gradually becomes more frequent
and forceful. Significant physical findings are a palpable abdominal mass and visible peristaltic waves in the
upper abdomen.
(Choice B) Duodenal atresia usually presents with bilious vomiting a few hours after the first feeding. It is
usually associated with other congenital anomalies, and can be a feature of Down's syndrome.
(Choice D) Hirschsprung's disease usually presents with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours.
In this disease, an aganglionic segment of the colon causes the intestinal obstruction.
(Choice E) Meconium ileus is a manifestation of cystic fibrosis, and usually presents with failure to pass
meconium within the first 24 hours after birth.
Educational Objective:
Midgut volvulus usually presents in a child less than one month of age as bilious vomiting, abdominal
distension and passage of bloodstained stools.

question:
A married couple brings their 2-week-old infant to the office for the evaluation of lethargy, poor feeding and
hypotonia. The infant was "fine" until yesterday, when he started to present with these symptoms. The
mother's medical history is unremarkable, and her pregnancy was uneventful. On examination, hypotonia,
poor reflexes and bulging fontanel are noted. There are no focal neurological signs. He is hypotensive and
tachycardiac. His temperature is 39.4 C (103F). Initial investigation reveals a WBC count of 16,000/cmm
with 18% bands. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Group B streptococcus is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis. It is part of the normal vaginal flora of
women and is transmitted to infants during passage through the birth canal. In neonates, infection presents
either as early-onset sepsis or late-onset sepsis. Early sepsis presents within the first week of life and
usually involves several organs. Symptoms include respiratory failure, meningitis, DIC, acute tubular
necrosis and peripheral gangrene. It is usually refractory to therapy and quickly evolves to shock, coma and
death.
Late-onset GBS infection is usually a focal infection, most frequently meningitis (75%), although arthritis,
osteomyelitis, cellulitis and urinary tract infection may also occur. Meningitis presents with fever, lethargy,
poor feeding, hypotonia, seizures and a bulging fontanel. The diagnosis is confirmed by positive blood or
cerebrospinal fluid cultures, although all newborns with fever and sepsis should have full workup for sepsis,
including urine cultures. If the mother has already received antibiotics, culture results may be negative and a
latex agglutination test may be more helpful.
(Choice A) Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with microcephaly, microphthalmia,
hepatosplenomegaly and chorioretinitis. The infant in this case has meningitis with a septic picture.
(Choice D) Herpes simplex virus encephalitis usually presents with focal neurologic signs, which are absent
in this case. Herpes involves temporal lobes, so patients may present with seizures. Moreover, an elevated
WBC count with bands correlate more with bacterial infections.
(Choice C) Escherichia coli meningitis is less frequent than GBS meningitis. It is the second most common
cause of neonatal meningitidis.
(Choice E) Listeria is the third most common cause of neonatal meningitis. It also tends to result in multiple
abscesses and pneumonia, in addition to meningitis.
Educational Objective:
Group B streptococcus is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis. Early sepsis presents in the first
week of life and usually involves several organs. Late-onset GBS infection is usually a focal infection, and is
most frequently meningitis (75%).

question:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain. She
has nausea and vomiting, and her stools contain blood and mucus. Her parents say that she was in her
usual state of health when she developed this problem. Her pulse rate is 116/min, blood pressure is
90/60mm Hg, temperature is 37.7C(100F), and respirations are 28/min. She looks lethargic and ill. She is
crying and drawing her knees towards her chest. Her abdomen is tender to palpation, and there is a
palpable, sausage-like abdominal mass. The bowel sounds are increased, and rectal examination reveals
bloody mucus. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
explanation:
This child has an intussusception. She has the typical presentation: 2-year old child with abdominal pain of
abrupt onset, nausea, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools containing blood and mucus. Intussusception is
one of the most frequent causes of intestinal obstruction in the first 2 years of life, with 75% of patients
younger than 1 year. The cause is mostly idiopathic, but in some cases, it is secondary to an intestinal mass
such as polyp, lymphoma, hamartoma, enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes, enlarged Peyer's patches, or
Meckel's diverticulum. The most common type of intussusception is ileocolic.
(Choice A) Patients with pyloric stenosis present with non-bilious vomiting and an olive-shaped mass in the
epigastrium. They don't have any blood or mucus in their stools.
(Choice C) Henoch-Schonlein purpura presents as a rash around the buttocks, abdominal pain, arthritis and
nephropathy.
(Choice D) Meckel's diverticulum usually presents at 2 years of age as painless rectal bleeding.
(Choice E) Some children with lymphoma may present with intussusception, but they are usually older
than children with the idiopathic form.
Educational Objective:
Intussusception is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in the first two years of life. In addition to
the signs of intestinal obstruction (e.g., severe, sudden-onset abdominal pain and vomiting), patients present
with red currant jelly stools containing blood and mucus.

question:
A 3-year-old male infant is brought to the office by his parents because he is withdrawn, does not play and
has a deficiency in language skills, when compared to his peers. His antenatal history is insignificant, but he
presented with severe hypotonia at birth. His family history is unremarkable. He eats "too much", which often
obliges his parents to restrain him from eating. He is obese and has a peculiar dysmorphic facies consisting
of narrow bifrontal diameter, almond-shaped eyes, a small, down-turned mouth, small hands and small feet.
His height is below the 5th percentile. Physical examination reveals hypotonia, microphallus, cryptorchidism,
and delayed developmental milestones. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), which is a sporadic disorder. In 50-70 percent of cases,
there is a deletion in the long arm of chromosome 15. PWS displays a particular type of genetic
transmission called genomic imprinting, wherein the phenotype expression depends on whether the genetic
defect is inherited from the mother or the father. The characteristic clinical presentation is severe hypotonia
at birth or infancy, hyperphagia, obesity, short stature and mental retardation. The typical craniofacial
features are narrow bifrontal diameter, diamond-shaped eyes and a small, down-turned mouth.
Hypothalamic dysfunctions (i.e., GH deficiency and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) may be present. The
associated short stature, obesity and hypotonia usually respond to GH administration; however, the
implication of GH deficiency accompanying PWS in the development of these features is still controversial.
(Choice B) Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by neonatal
hypoglycemia, macroglossia, large size, visceromegaly, omphalocele and a characteristic earlobe crease.
(Choice C) Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by a deficiency in hypoxanthine-guanine
phosphoribosyl transferase, an enzyme involved in purine metabolism. It is characterized by self-mutilation,
mental retardation, hyperuricemia and neurologic signs (e g., dystonia, choreoathetosis and cerebral palsy).
(Choice D) Patau's syndrome, or trisomy 13, is characterized by scalp defects (cutis aplasia), cleft lip or
palate, microcephaly, hypotelorism, flexed fingers with polydactyly and congenital heart defects. 90 to 95
percent of babies with Patau's syndrome die before their first birthday.
(Choice E) Edward's syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by low birth weight, closed fists (with the
index finger overlapping the third finger, and the fifth finger overlapping the fourth), microcephaly, prominent
occiput, rocker bottom feet and renal/cardiac malformations. Up to 95 percent of infants with trisomy 18 die
within the first month of life. Only 5 percent survive to one year.
*If you see a vignette with a child that is >=2-years-old, it is unlikely that the diagnosis is Patau's or Edward's
syndrome.
Educational Objective:
The features of Prader-Willi syndrome (obesity hypogonadism syndrome) include hypotonia, hypogonadism
and obesity. Remember mental retardation and the dysmorphic craniofacial features (i.e., narrow bifrontal
diameter, diamond-shaped eyes and a small, down-turned mouth).
*Certain classic syndromes are important for USMLE exams. We will be giving only the syndromes which
are likely to appear on the exam.

question:
A neonate born at term is found to have webbed neck and swollen hands and feet. Ultrasonogram of the
abdomen shows a horseshoe kidney. Which of the following is the most likely cause of edema?
options: A. Immune mediated red cell destruction
B. Dysgenesis of the lymphatic network
D. Increased urinary loss of protein
explanation:
This patient has a webbed neck, which along with a high palate, a short fourth metacarpal, and nail dysplasia
are common physical exam findings in newborns with Turner syndrome. Patients with Turner syndrome
have a higher risk of renal abnormalities, particularly horseshoe kidney, and should have a screening
ultrasound after the diagnosis is made. This patient's swollen hands and feet are likely due do congenital
lymphedema, which is common in patients with Turner syndrome due to abnormal development of the
lymphatic network. Edema that is due to lymphedema is generally nonpitting on physical exam as opposed
to the pitting edema seen with CHF, liver failure, or nephrotic syndrome.
(Choice A) Immune mediated red cell destruction is the pathophysiologic mechanism involved in hemolytic
disease of the newborn, where maternal antibodies to the Rh antigen attack the newborn's red blood
cells. Infants with severe hemolytic anemia may have hydrops fetalis (generalized edema).
(Choice C) Liver failure can cause pitting edema due to decreased synthesis of albumin, but is unlikely to be
present at birth and the other features in this patient are more suggestive of Turner syndrome.
(Choice D) Increased urinary protein loss, as is seen in nephrotic syndrome, can lead to peripheral pitting
edema. Again, it is uncommon at birth and the other clinical features in this patient point towards Turner
syndrome.
(Choice E) Perinatal hypoxia has many detrimental effects to the brain, lungs, heart, and gastrointestinal
systems. However, peripheral edema is not generally one of the manifestations unless there is severe heart
failure.
Educational objective:
Turner syndrome should be considered in newborns with a webbed neck, high palate, short fourth
metacarpal, and nail dysplasia. Lymphedema frequently occurs due to abnormal development of the
lymphatic system.

question:
An 11-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother due to headaches for the last 4 hours. The
headaches are bifrontal, and are accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and noise. It is her
second episode, and both episodes were preceded by dark spots in her visual field. The first episode was 2
weeks ago. She doesn't report any numbness or tingling in her extremities, and no behavioral change or
decline in school performance was noted. Her vital signs are stable and she is afebrile. The physical
examination is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: C. CT scan of the head
explanation:
This patient most likely has migraine headaches with aura. Migraine headaches are the most common
cause of headaches in the pediatric population, occurring in 50% of cases before the age of 20 years. The
aura can be visual (e.g. blurred vision, scotoma, photophobia, distortion of objects) or sensory (e.g, perioral
paresthesia, numbness of extremities, shoulder pain, abdominal pain, otalgia). Migraine headache is a
clinical diagnosis, and further investigations are not usually indicated. Neuroimaging is required only when
there are behavioral changes, decline in school performance, decline in growth parameters, early morning
headaches, seizures, or abnormal neurologic findings. In complicated migraines, neurologic signs (e.g,
basilar signs, ophthalmoplegia, or hemiparesis) may be present, although the work-up reveals nothing
abnormal. These neurologic symptoms may last only during the headache or persist for several days or
weeks.
(Choice B) A lumbar puncture would be indicated if the patient had fever, neck stiffness or any other
meningeal signs.
(Choices C, D and E) Neurological exam is normal, so neuroimaging studies and EEG are not indicated.
Educational Objective:
No investigations are needed in the case of migraine headache, unless the neurological exam is abnormal
and/or fever is present. Migraine is a clinical diagnosis, and the initial treatment is acetaminophen or NSAIDs.

question:
A previously healthy one-year-old child is brought to the physician for a routine wellness visit. Her parents
report that she drinks six glasses of whole milk a day, but is a very picky eater. She is developmentally
appropriate. Her parents are concerned that she might be anemic because she frequently eats ice and
sometimes dirt. On examination, her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 118/min, and respiratory rate is
21/min. Her height and weight are both at the 50% percentile for her age. She appears well nourished and
her physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings include the following.
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin                  10.5 g/dL
MCV                             70 fL
Reticulocytes                      1.0%
Platelets                         250,000/mm³
Leukocyte count            8,500/mm³
Neutrophils               50%
Lymphocytes               33%
Monocytes               10%
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child?
explanation:
Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional deficiency in children. At birth, the iron stores of the infant are
dependent upon the mother's iron stores, any prenatal or perinatal hemorrhage, and the gestational age of the
infant at delivery, with prematurity a risk factor for iron deficiency. Term infants usually have adequate iron
stores to sustain them for the first six months of life. After six months, dietary factors (eg, insufficient intake,
malabsorption) become the most important cause of iron deficiency. Early introduction to or excessive intake
of cow's milk is of particular concern because cow's milk is low in iron and can cause occult intestinal blood
loss in infants. Children should not be started on cow's milk until one year of age, and children between one
and five years old should not consume more than 20 ounces of milk a day.
Children with iron deficiency are often asymptomatic, with the diagnosis based on the complete blood
count. Important clues in the history and physical examination include predisposing factors such as poor
nutrition and signs and symptoms such as pica, fatigue, and pallor. A peripheral smear demonstrates
microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes. Further testing is not necessary in children with the classic
presentation. The most cost effective treatment approach is oral iron therapy. Repeat hemoglobin should be
checked in four weeks: If the hemoglobin level has risen 1 g/dL, then the oral iron therapy should be continued
until the hemoglobin normalizes.
(Choices A, B, and C) If the anemia does not resolve with empiric iron therapy and appropriate dietary
changes, other causes must be considered. Hemoglobin electrophoresis (for hereditary anemias),
colonoscopy (for lower gastrointestinal tract bleeding), or serum creatinine measurement (for renal disease)
may be indicated.
(Choice E) Blood transfusions are rarely necessary in the treatment of dietary iron deficiency anemia, even
when the hemoglobin is 4-5 g/dL. Iron therapy should be sufficient.
Educational objective:
Iron deficiency anemia is common in infants and toddlers who drink excessive amounts of cow's
milk. Empiric oral iron therapy is appropriate for children with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

question:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because he is developing dark facial hair, deepening
of the voice and a rapid height increase. He also complains of persistent headaches which are resistant to
over-the-counter analgesics for the past 2 weeks. He denies nausea, vomiting or visual disturbances. His
medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals coarse pubic and axillary hair. Other
pertinent findings include lid retraction, paralysis of upward and downward gaze, and poor pupillary reaction to
light. His deep tendon reflexes are normal, Babinski sign is negative, and there are no focal neurologic signs.
What tumor is most likely responsible for this child's symptoms?
explanation:
This patient has Parinaud's syndrome, which consists of paralysis of vertical gaze that may be associated
with pupillary disturbances and eyelid retraction (Collier's sign). The involved lesion is on the rostral midbrain
at the level of the superior colliculus and CN III. It is most commonly caused by germinomas and pinealomas
at this region. The endocrine syndrome results from interruption of hypothalamic inhibiting pathways, and
sometimes beta-hCG secretion and consequent Leydig's cell stimulation.
(Choice A) In 90% of cases, medulloblastoma arises from the cerebellar vermis, and is not associated with
Parinaud's syndrome.
(Choice B) Neuroblastoma is the third most common malignancy in the pediatric population. It arises most
frequently from the adrenal glands and sympathetic paraspinal ganglia.
(Choice C) Oligodendroglioma is a less common type of brain tumor in children.
(Choice D) Although craniopharyngioma can also cause an endocrine syndrome, it results in visual field
defects owing to its sellar location.
Educational Objective:
Parinaud's syndrome and Collier's sign usually indicate a lesion in the rostral midbrain, most likely pinealoma
or germinoma.

question:
A mother brings her daughter into the clinic for a routine health-care visit. On examination, you note that she
walks alone, knows two words, throws objects, and comes when called. What is the most likely age of this
infant?
explanation:
The developmental features described here are found in children of 12 months of age. The following
developmental milestones are the most commonly known, so it would be fairly enough to memorize them.
Language development:
Social smiles: 2 months
Babbles: 6 months
2 words, obeys 1-step command: 1 year
2-3 word phrases, obeys 2-step command: 2 years
Gross motor development:
Holds head: 3 months
Rolls back to front and front to back: 4 months
Sits well unsupported: 6 months
Walks alone: 12 months
Walks up and down stairs without help: 24 months
Fine motor development:
Raking grasp: 6 months
Throws object: 12 months
Builds tower of 2 blocks: 15 months
Builds tower of 6 blocks/turn pages of books: 24 months
Social development:
Recognizes parents: 2 months
Recognizes strangers (stranger anxiety): 6 months
Imitates action/comes when called: 12 months
Plays with other children: 18 months
Parallel play: 24 months
Educational Objective:
A 12-month-old child walks alone, speaks two words, throws objects, and comes when called.

question:
A 16-year-old Caucasian male presents to the office with pain and limited motion of the right knee. His right
knee, as well as his right ankle, has swelled several times before. He has a history of easy bruising since
childhood, and an episode of excessive bleeding after a tooth extraction. His uncle had similar problems.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's joint pain?
explanation:
This patient's history (e.g., bruising since childhood and an episode of excessive bleeding after a tooth
extraction) is consistent with hemophilia. His several episodes of joint swelling are more likely related to
hemarthroses. Recurrent hemarthroses may then lead to a joint injury called 'hemophilic arthropathy'.
Although the exact mechanism underlying the joint damage is not known, iron deposition and synovial
thickening with fibrosis are characteristic. Iron deposition and cytokines released from the blood stimulate
synovial proliferation, fibrosis and cartilage injury.
The other mechanisms of joint injury that are listed are not applicable to this case.
(Choice C) Immunologic tissue injury occurs in rheumatoid arthritis.
(Choice D) Wear-and-tear injury is implicated in degenerative osteoarthritis.
(Choice F) Ischemic necrosis that usually involves femoral heads may be caused by fractures, vascular
occlusion or treatment with corticosteroids.
(Choice G) Crystal deposition causes acute inflammation, and is responsible for gout and pseudogout.
Educational Objective:
Recurrent hemarthroses in patients with coagulopathies lead to a joint injury called 'hemophilic arthropathy'.

question:
A 12-week-old female infant is brought to the office by her mother due to a three-week history of weakness,
poor appetite, and choking spells during feeding. Other accompanying symptoms include excessive
sleeping, constipation and apathy. Her prenatal history is unremarkable. She was delivered vaginally at 38
weeks of gestation. Her weight and length at birth were within normal range. She is exclusively breastfed.
Her mother's family history is unremarkable. The identity and family history of her father are unknown. The
pertinent physical findings include apathy, weakness, hypotonia, large tongue, sluggish movement, abdominal
bloating, and an umbilical hernia. Based on the given information, what is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This clinical case is characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, which may be familial or sporadic. The most
common cause is thyroid dysgenesis (i.e, aplasia, hypoplasia, or ectopic gland), which has been
incriminated in 85% of cases. Other causes include inborn errors of thyroxin synthesis (10%), and
transplacental maternal thyrotropin-receptor blocking antibodies (5%). Infants initially appear normal at birth,
but gradually develop apathy, weakness, hypotonia, large tongue, sluggish movement, abdominal bloating,
and an umbilical hernia. Other signs include pathologic jaundice, difficult breathing, noisy respiration,
hypothermia, and refractory macrocytic anemia. Infants initially appear normal due to the presence of
moderate amounts of maternal hormones in the infant's circulation. For this reason, screening is mandated
in all states at birth to allow for the early detection, treatment, and consequent improvement of the prognosis.
Screening is done by measuring serum T4 and TSH levels. The treatment is levothyroxine (initial dose of 10
mg/kg, then titrated accordingly).
(Choice A) Infant botulism occurs most commonly in infants whose diet includes honey or canned food.
This infant has been exclusively breastfed since birth. Furthermore, patients with botulism do not present
with a large tongue, umbilical hernia, and apathy, which are all classic features of hypothyroidism.
(Choice B) Werdnig-Hoffman syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that involves degeneration of the
anterior horn cells and cranial nerve motor nuclei. It is a cause of "floppy baby" syndrome (the other cause is
infant botulism).
(Choice C) Myotonic congenital myopathy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by muscle
weakness and atrophy (most predominant in the distal muscles of the upper and lower extremities),
myotonia, testicular atrophy, and baldness.
(Choice E) Myasthenia gravis presents with easy fatigability and weakness that improves with rest. The
pediatric form occurs in late childhood or adolescence.
Educational Objective:
Infants with congenital hypothyroidism initially appear normal at birth, but gradually develop apathy, weakness,
hypotonia, large tongue, sluggish movement, abdominal bloating, and an umbilical hernia. For this reason,
screening newborns for hypothyroidism, along with phenylketonuria and galactosemia, is standardly
performed in all states.

question:
While making rounds in the newborn nursery, the nurses ask you to examine a 2-day-old infant who is not
feeding well. The nurse reports that the infant is irritable, is not sleeping well, and has had several episodes
of vomiting and loose stools today. A review of the maternal history reveals that she had poor prenatal care
and the pregnancy was complicated by intrauterine growth restriction. On examination, the infant is
diaphaoretic and has a high-pitched cry. The infant is also noted to have occasional sneezing and is mildly
tachypneic. No dysmorphic features are noted and the remainder of the examination is unremarkable. This
infant's symptoms are most likely caused by prenatal exposure to which of the following?
explanation:
Although most drugs of abuse cause an addiction in both the mother and the fetus, opiates have the most
dramatic effects on the fetus. The opiates that infants are most commonly exposed to are heroin and
methadone. Methadone is prescribed for pregnant women who are addicted to heroin to prevent uncontrolled
withdrawal in the fetus. Heroin and methadone are not associated with dysmorphic features or congenital
anomalies in the fetus, but prenatal exposure can lead to an increased risk of intrauterine growth retardation,
macrocephaly, sudden infant death syndrome, and neonatal abstinence syndrome (NAS).
NAS usually presents in the first few days of life and is characterized by irritability, a high-pitched cry, poor
sleeping, tremors, seizures, sweating, sneezing, tachypnea, poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea.
Withdrawal usually presents within 48 hours after birth for heroin withdrawal and between 48 and 72 hours for
methadone withdrawal, although it can be delayed up to four weeks. The treatment for NAS includes
symptomatic care to calm the infant and help the infant sleep, such as swaddling, providing small frequent
feeds, and keeping the infant in a low stimulation environment. Pharmacologic treatment should be used
when supportive treatment does not control the infant's withdrawal symptoms. Morphine can be
administered and systematically weaned to help control opiate withdrawal.
(Choice A) Fetal exposure to valproic acid significantly increases the risk of neural tube defects, may result
in cardiac anomalies, and can produce dysmorphic facies, including a cleft lip, narrow bifrontal diameter,
midface hypoplasia, broad and depressed nasal bridge, and long philtrum.
(Choice B) Prenatal exposure to phenytoin can result in fetal hydantoin syndrome, which is characterized by
nail and digit hypoplasia, dysmorphic facies, and mental retardation. Growth deficiency can also be seen.
(Choice C) Fetal alcohol syndrome consists of growth deficiency, presence of a long, smooth philtrum, small
palpebral fissures, and a thin upper lip in addition to central nervous system abnormalities such as mental
retardation. Withdrawal symptoms are usually not seen unless the mother was drinking just prior to delivery.
(Choice D) Prenatal exposure to cocaine can result in jitteriness, excessive sucking, and a hyperactive Moro
reflex. Withdrawal symptoms are usually not as severe as with opiates. Long-term effects on behavior,
attention level, and intelligence may be seen.
Educational objective:
Neonatal abstinence syndrome is caused by infant withdrawal to opiates and usually presents in the first few
days of life. It is characterized by irritability, a high-pitched cry, poor sleeping, tremors, seizures, sweating,
sneezing, tachypnea, poor feeding, vomiting, and diarrhea.

question:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. The
mother says that he was "fine" a few days ago, and then suddenly became ill. Physical examination shows a
pale and jaundiced child. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness and 2+ pedal edema. Laboratory studies
show anemia, thrombocytopenia and renal insufficiency. What is the most likely cause of the patient's
symptoms?
explanation:
This patient has hemolytic-uremic syndrome, which is caused by a toxin released by Escherichia coli. The
verotoxin invades and destroys the colonic epithelial lining, and produces a bloody diarrhea. Subsequent
activation of the coagulation system and red cell hemolysis results in jaundice. HUS is more common in
children aged one- to four-years-old, and the initial presentation includes abdominal pain and diarrhea. The
classic triad of HUS is uremia, thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia. Investigations include CBC, platelet
count, blood smear, urinalysis, BUN and creatinine. Treatment is generally supportive, and involves
plasmapheresis, dialysis if necessary, and steroids. Antibiotics are not indicated.
(Choice A) Cholera usually presents during an epidemic with an abrupt, watery, painless diarrhea. There
may be vomiting, and most patients are severely dehydrated. The treatment is fluid replacement.
(Choice C) Crohn's disease can affect any part of the Gl tract. It can present with fever, abdominal pain,
diarrhea (sometimes bloody), weight loss and rectal fissures. It generally has a gradual course, and is not
seen in the very young. There is no hemolysis or jaundice.
(Choice D) Lactose intolerance has features of chronic diarrhea (not bloody). It can present with abdominal
pain or cramps, and is usually associated with ingestion of dairy products. It is more common in Asians and
Africans. The diagnosis is suggested by: (1) improvement of symptoms after abstaining from dairy
products, (2) acid pH of the stools, and (3) presence of positive reducing sugars. The diagnosis is confirmed
by a positive hydrogen breath test.
(Choice E) Salmonella poisoning is usually due to ingestion of contaminated water, food or milk. It can
present with general malaise, fever, and an erythematous rash on the abdomen (Rose spots). Most
individuals have diarrhea for several weeks. Stool cultures are diagnostic. If untreated, the disease can
progress to involve the brain, bone, kidney and joints.
(Choice F) Even though Campylobacter jejuni can cause bloody diarrhea, it does not cause
thrombocytopenia. Renal failure can be seen with any diarrhea secondary to dehydration and prerenal
azotemia.
Educational Objective:
Suspect hemolytic uremic syndrome in a child with sudden-onset abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and triad
of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal failure.

question:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his Caucasian mother because his speech is difficult to
understand. He is a very slow learner, is unusually calm, stays to himself, doesn't hug his parents, prefers to
play by himself, speaks in mumbles, and repetitively tries to make towers with cubes. He becomes very
aggressive if he is stopped from his activities. He was born at term from an uncomplicated pregnancy and
delivery, and his physical growth has been normal. His brother used to be aggressive as a child, and was
diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. In the office, the patient is sitting quietly and trying to
make towers with cubes. He seems to be oblivious of his environment. On calling his name thrice, he turns
towards you once and then resumes playing with the cubes. What do you tell his mother?
options: A. He has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and would benefit from methylphenidate
B. This could be autism and would benefit from antipsychotics
C. He has hearing problems and he needs ear, nose and throat evaluation
D. He has autism and will need special behavioral and educational programs
E. His diagnosis is Asperger syndrome
explanation:
Autism, also called pervasive developmental disorder, is characterized by impairments in social
interaction and communication, stereotypical behaviors, and delayed language development. Lack of peer
relationship and nonverbal social cues, delayed social smile, repetitive activities and preference for
sameness are also very commonly seen in these kids. Self-injurious behavior and aggressiveness when
changed from their routines have also been noticed. The mainstays of treatment include special education
and behavioral modification techniques.
(Choice A) The patient does not have any features of ADHD, such as impulsiveness, inattentiveness, or
hyperactivity.
(Choice B) No pharmacological agent has been found to be useful in autism; however, antipsychotics can be
used in patients who are aggressive or have self-injurious behavior, but not as an initial measure.
(Choice C) Deafness can easily be confused with autism, but in this case, the boy turned when his name
was called. Moreover, deaf children are usually affectionate and hug their parents, and their nonverbal social
cues are normal. Even though deafness still has to be ruled out as part of this patient's evaluation,
the features of this patient make autism the most likely diagnosis.
(Choice E) Asperger syndrome is another close differential diagnosis of autism, but these kids are usually
more socially aware and communicative. Although patients may have features of stereotypical movements
and self-injurious behavior, their language development is normal. In this case, the patient's language
development is delayed, hence autism is a better choice.
Educational Objective:
Always think of autism first in any patient who is less than 3 years old and presents with impairment in social
interactions and communication, delayed language development, and stereotypical behaviors.

question:
A two-day old infant develops seizures, bulging fontanel, and focal neurologic signs. His temperature is 37 C
(98F), pulse is 180/min, and capillary refill is >= 2 seconds. The initial work-up reveals a hemoglobin level of
12g/dL. Transfontanel ultrasonography demonstrates a hemorrhage involving the germinal matrix, lateral
ventricles, and brain parenchyma. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for this newborn's
condition?
explanation:
This newborn most likely has a Grade 4 intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), which results from bleeding in the
germinal matrix, and occurs predominantly in premature and low-birth-weight (LBW) infants. Studies have
shown that the incidence of IVH is inversely proportional to birth weight (the lower the birth weight, the greater
the likelihood of IVH). Exposure to vascular perfusion injuries have also been associated with IVH. Examples
of such events are: (1) hypoxic or ischemic episodes, (2) hypotension, (3) reperfusion of damaged vessels,
(4) increased venous pressure, and (4) abrupt changes in cerebral flow. Patients may present with pallor,
cyanosis, hypotension, seizures, focal neurologic signs, bulging or tense fontanel, apnea and bradycardia;
however, many cases remain asymptomatic, thus mandating transfontanel ultrasound for all newborns with
predisposing risk factors. IVH is subdivided into 4 grades, according to the severity of the bleeding.
Long-term sequelae include motor and intellectual disabilities, and are seen mainly in severe forms (grade 3
and 4).
(Choices B, C, D and E) Pelvic dystocia, prenatal infections, congenital anomalies, and macrosomia are not
directly incriminated in IVH.
Educational Objective:
IVH is most commonly seen in premature and LBW infants. Patients may present with pallor, cyanosis,
hypotension, seizures, focal neurologic signs, bulging or tense fontanel, apnea and bradycardia; however,
many cases remain asymptomatic, thus mandating transfontanel ultrasound for all newborns with
predisposing risk factors.

question:
A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Her birth history is significant for low birth
weight and bilateral swelling of the hands and feet. Her blood pressure is 170/96 mmHg. She has a short
stature and webbed neck. Her karyotype examination results show 22 pairs of autosomes, one X, and one Y
chromosome. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's condition?
options: A. The primary amenorrhea in this girl is most likely caused by functional uterine abnormalities
B. The girl should undergo bilateral abdominal gonadectomy
C. The webbing of the neck is caused by defects in arteriovenous communications
D. The inheritance for this condition is Mendelian dominant
E. This child will benefit from steroid hormone replacement therapy
explanation:
This patient has Turner's syndrome, and although the usual karyotypic finding is 45, XO (i.e., 22 pairs of
autosomes and a single X chromosome), variations are possible. The karyotype in this case (i.e. 46, XY) is
associated with a higher risk of gonadoblastoma; hence, prophylactic bilateral gonadectomy is indicated in
this patient.
(Choice A) The primary amenorrhea seen in Turner's syndrome is due to ovarian failure, and not to uterine
abnormalities.
(Choice C) The webbing of the neck is due to lymphatic channel abnormalities, and not to arteriovenous
miscommunications.
(Choice D) Turner's syndrome is inherited in a sporadic fashion, and not as an autosomal dominant trait.
(Choice E) Patients with Turner's syndrome should be treated with growth hormones, not steroids, when
their height falls below the 5th percentile on the normal growth curve. Therapy is continued until the bone age
is greater than 15 years, and the growth rate falls to less than 2 cm.
Educational Objective:
Turner's syndrome with 46 XY karyotype is associated with a higher incidence of gonadoblastoma; hence,
prophylactic bilateral gonadectomy is indicated in the management of such patients.

question:
A term newborn infant from an uncomplicated pregnancy is being examined. He is pink, except for his
extremities, which are blue. His heart rate is 150/min, and his respirations are irregular and slow at 40/min.
He coughs on nasal stimulation and has some flexion of the extremities. What is his Apgar score?
explanation:
The Apgar score is measured in newborns at 0 and 5 minutes of life. It has five components, and is scored
as follows:
Color of the newborn:
0 body and extremities are blue/pale
1 body is pink and extremities are blue
2 body and extremities are pink
Heart rate:
0 heart shows no activity
1 HR < 100 beats/min
2 HR >= 100 beats/min
Reaction to nasal stimulation:
0 no response to stimulation
1 grimace
2 active cough
Tone/Activity:
0 limp
1 some flexion of extremities
2 active flexion of extremities
Respirations:
0 completely absent
1 slow and irregular
2 good respiratory effort
In this newborn, the score for color is 1, heart rate is 2, reaction to nasal stimulation is 2, tone/activity is 1,
and respirations is 1; therefore, his Apgar score is 7/10.
Educational Objective:
Know how to calculate an Apgar score.

question:
A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic for the evaluation of poor feeding. He was born at 32 weeks of
gestation with a birth weight of 1200 g. The pertinent physical findings are pallor, tachypnea, tachycardia, and
flow murmurs. The laboratory studies are as follows:
Hb                     7 g/dL
WBC                  7,000/cmm
Platelets               230,000/cmm
Reticulocytes          Low
The peripheral smear shows normocytic normochromic RBC. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Anemia of prematurity is seen in hospitalized, premature or low birth weight infants. The causes are usually
pathophysiologic, and include: (1) transitions in the erythropoiesis sites of the neonate, (2) shorter life span of
red blood cells in neonates, and (3) diminished fetaplacental transfusion (occurs when the baby is held above
the level of the placenta after delivery). Symptoms include poor weight gain, poor feeding, lethargy,
tachypnea, tachycardia, and pallor. The hemoglobin level is usually around 7-10 g/dL.
Anemia of prematurity is defined by the following laboratory studies:
1. Peripheral smear shows normocytic and normochromic anemia. No other abnormal forms are seen.
2. The reticulocyte count is low, and red blood cell precursors in the bone marrow are decreased.
3. Normal WBC and platelet counts.
4. Normal total bilirubin level.
The treatment involves iron supplementation, periodic hemoglobin checking and blood transfusion, if needed.
Erythropoietin is not routinely used.
(Choice A) Alpha thalassemia is caused by abnormalities in the synthesis of alpha chains of hemoglobin. It
is usually a hypochromic, microcytic anemia, and a positive family history is usually present.
(Choice B) Beta thalassemia is also a hypochromic, microcytic anemia that usually presents at 6-12 months
of age.
(Choice C) Hemolytic disease of the newborn is due to Rh or ABO incompatibility. The clinical features
depend on the severity of the disease. Symptoms include jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and hydrops
fetalis in severe cases. The reticulocyte count is increased due to hemolysis.
(Choice D) Sickle cell anemia presents much later because the presence of hemoglobin F protects the
infants from sickling during the first 4-6 months of life. Dactylitis may be the initial presentation that warrants
further work-up for sickle cell disease.
(Choice F) Even though iron supplementation is routinely administered in the management of anemia of
prematurity, iron deficiency is not the usual cause. Iron is given because it will be stored and reutilized during
the active phase of erythropoiesis.
(Choice G) Low levels of folic acid or vitamin B12 do not cause anemia of prematurity. Furthermore, the
anemia in such cases is megaloblastic.
Educational Objective:
Anemia of prematurity is the most common anemia in premature and low birth weigh infants. The pathology
involves a combination of diminished RBC production, shortened RBC life span, and blood loss. Iron
supplementation does not prevent falling hemoglobin levels, and iron deficiency is not the cause of anemia of
prematurity.

question:
A 9-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after having a seizure. He is visiting his
grandparents for the weekend. His past medical history is insignificant. When the grandmother is
questioned about any medications, she replies with, "He isn't taking any medications, but I'm taking
nortriptyline, and my husband is taking atenolol and enalapril" The boy's blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and
pulse is 90/min. Physical examination reveals dry oral mucosa and dilated pupils. His answers are
adequate, but delayed. EKG shows wide QRS complexes. What is the best next step in the management of
this patient?
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of severe tricyclic antidepressant intoxication. The
characteristic features include seizure, hypotension, and prolonged QRS complexes on EKG. The first steps
in the management of this pediatric emergency are the ABC's (airway, breathing, circulation). Patent airways
and adequate breathing should be ascertained, and cardiac monitors, oximetry, and IV lines should be
established. Sodium bicarbonate is given to correct the associated acidosis, and helps to narrow the QRS
complex and to control hypotension.
(Choice A) Physostigmine is used to correct the anticholinergic effects of tricyclic antidepressants during
mild intoxication, but is never used in severe intoxication.
(Choice B) Beta-blockers are avoided during tricyclic antidepressant intoxication.
(Choice D) Prolonged seizures are treated with benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam). Phenytoin is usually not
used, because it can increase the frequency of ventricular arrhythmias.
(Choice E) In this situation, immediate actions should be undertaken to save the patient's life.
Educational Objective:
The treatment for tricyclic antidepressant intoxication includes sodium bicarbonate. This drug not only helps
to correct the acidosis, but also helps to narrow the QRS complex prolongation. Benzodiazepine (eg,
diazepam) is given when the patient presents with seizures that require treatment.
*Extremely high yield question for USMLE!!!

question:
A 1-month-old infant is brought to the office for a routine neonatal visit. His prenatal and birth histories are
unremarkable. His vital signs are normal. Examination reveals a harsh, loud holosystolic murmur over the
left, lower sternal border. Palpation reveals a thrill over the precordial region. There is no cyanosis, and
pulmonary auscultation reveals no rales. Chest radiograph reveals a heart of normal size and a slight
increase in pulmonary vascularity. EKG is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of
action?
explanation:
This patient's murmur (i.e., harsh and holosystolic heard at the left, lower sternal border) is characteristic of
ventricular septal defect (VSD). VSD accounts for 25% of all congenital heart diseases, making it the most
common type. In this case, the defect is likely to be small, as suggested by the absence of symptoms (apart
from the murmur), harsh and loud murmur, normal EKG and slight vascular markings on chest x-ray. In
small VSDs, the volume of the left-to-right shunt remains small even after the postnatal decline in pulmonary
resistance. The pulmonary circulation is thus protected, and symptoms which would otherwise appear due
to the increased blood volume in the lungs, are absent. Small VSDs close spontaneously in 40% of cases
by three years and in 75% by 10 years, so reassurance and surveillance are all that are needed. The risk of
infective endocarditis is increased in the long run; therefore, antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated prior to dental
visits and other oropharyngeal surgical procedures.
In large defects (soft murmur), the postnatal decrease in pulmonary resistance leads to an increase in blood
flow through the shunt and a rise in pulmonary pressure. The resultant symptoms include chronic lower
respiratory infections, growth failure, and congestive heart failure. The constant, increased pressure involving
the pulmonary circulation results in irreversible vascular changes and consequent Eisenmenger syndrome
(cyanosis, chest pain, dyspnea, and shortness of breath due to reversal of the shunt from left-to-right to
right-to-left). The treatment depends on the size of the defect and severity of symptoms, but is generally a
combination of medication and surgery. Treatment should be initiated before pulmonary vascular changes
become irreversible (Eisenmenger syndrome).
(Choice A) PGE1 is a prostaglandin that is administered to keep the ductus arteriosus open in infants with:
(1) lesions in which systemic blood flow or pulmonary blood flow is ductal dependant, and (2) mixing lesions
without adequate mixing (d-TGA with intact ventricular septum).
(Choices B and C) As long as there are no symptoms, there is no need to administer oxygen, diuretics, or
digoxin. These are indicated when symptoms of cardiac decompensation appear.
(Choice D) Surgical repair is indicated in large or symptomatic defects.
Educational Objective:
Most small ventricular septal defects close spontaneously and require no treatment, as long as there are no
signs of pulmonary vascular disease. Reassurance, surveillance (via EKG and echocardiography), and
infective endocarditis prophylaxis are all that are needed for management.

question:
A term Caucasian male newborn is being examined. He weighs 2.6kg (5.8lb). He has closed fists, with his
index finger overlapping the 3rd digit, and his 5th digit overlapping the 4th. He also has microcephaly,
prominent occiput, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
This patient has the classic clinical presentation (i.e. low birth weight, closed fists with the index finger
overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th, microcephaly, prominent occiput, micrognathia,
rocker-bottom feet) of Edwards’ syndrome (trisomy 18). Other physical findings are narrow hips with limited
abduction, short sternum, cardiac and renal malformations, and mental retardation. Most patients
(approximately 95%) die during their first year of life.
(Choice A) Infants with Down syndrome (trisomy 21) usually present with hypotonia, flat face, upward and
slanted palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, Brushfield spots, dysplasia of the pelvis, cardiac malformations,
simian crease, short and broad hands, hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger, intestinal atresia,
and high arched palate. Mental and growth retardation may later occur. Down's syndrome is the most
common trisomy.
(Choice C) Infants with Patau's syndrome (trisomy 13) can present with cleft lip, flexed fingers with
polydactyly, ocular hypotelorism, bulbous nose, low-set malformed ears, small abnormal skull, cerebral
malformation, microphthalmia, cardiac malformations, scalp defects, hypoplastic or absent ribs, visceral and
genital anomalies. None of these are present in the above case.
(Choice D) Wolf-Hirschhorn's syndrome is very low-yield for the USMLE. You do not need to remember this
disease. Nevertheless, the cause of this condition is a chromosome 4p deletion. Characteristic findings
include a "Greek helmet" facies with ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella and frontal bossing, ptosis, and
strabismus. Other accompanying findings are microcephaly, dolichocephaly, hypoplasia of the eye sockets,
bilateral epicanthic folds, cleft lip and palate, beaked nose with prominent bridge, cardiac malformations and
mental retardation. Needless to say, none of these features are present in the above case.
(Choice E) Infants with cri-du-chat syndrome may also present with microcephaly; however, there is a
characteristic protruding metopic suture in such patients. Furthermore, the patient's cat-like cry will usually
be the tell-tale sign of this condition. Other accompanying manifestations are hypotonia, short
stature, moonlike face, hypertelorism, bilateral epicanthic folds, high arched palate, wide and flat nasal bridge,
and mental retardation. This condition is caused by a 5p deletion.
Educational Objective:
Infants with Edwards’ syndrome commonly present with microcephaly, prominent occiput, micrognathia,
closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th, and rocker bottom
feet.

question:
An 8-year-old girl is being evaluated for short stature. She is at 5th percentile for height and 3th percentile for
weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a high arched palate and inverted, widely
spaced nipples. Karyotyping shows 45 XO. Which of the following is she most at risk of developing?
explanation:
This patient's short height, high arched palate, widely spaced nipples, and 45 XO karyotype are all consistent
with a diagnosis of Turner syndrome. Patients with Turner syndrome are prone to the development of
osteoporosis which increases the risk of bone fracture. This increased risk is in part due to low estrogen
levels from gonadal dysgenesis. There is also thought to be increased risk from having only one copy of X
chromosome genes that may be involved in bone metabolism. Estrogen replacement therapy is given to
nearly all patients to promote normal maturation, but it also has the effect of reducing the risk of osteoporosis.
(Choice B) The most common cardiovascular abnormalities in Turner syndrome are coarctation of the aorta
and aortic valve abnormalities. Mitral valve prolapse is not very common.
(Choice C) Most patients with Turner syndrome have normal cognitive abilities.
(Choice D) There is no higher risk for development of bipolar disorder in patients with Turner syndrome.
(Choice E) Patients with Turner syndrome do not have any additional risk of breast cancer. Turner
syndrome patients have decreased estrogen levels, while elevated estrogen levels are a risk factor for breast
cancer.
Educational objective:
Short height, high arched palate, widely spaced nipples, and 45 XO karyotype are all features of Turner
syndrome. Patients with Turner syndrome have a higher risk of osteoporosis due to lower estrogen levels
and only having one copy of X chromosome genes involved in bone metabolism.

question:
A 16-week-old African-American infant is brought in for well-baby examination and immunization. On
examination, he is active and able to hold his head and smile. There is a flat, well-demarcated, gray lesion
over his sacral area. There are no similar spots anywhere else on his body. His mother says that this lesion
has been present since birth. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
explanation:
This case gives the classic description (i.e., well-demarcated, flat blue/gray lesion on the sacral or presacral
area) of a Mongolian spot. This lesion is seen more commonly in dark skinned children. It is caused by
entrapment of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, and usually disappears in the first few years of
life.
(Choice B) A bruise due to child abuse is possible, but is less likely than a Mongolian spot since a bruise
usually fades into the surrounding skin and has different colors, which is not the case here.
(Choice C) Cafe-au-lait spots are well-demarcated, tan or light brown flat lesions that can vary in number,
size, and distribution. This finding may indicate neurofibromatosis if the diameter is larger than 0.5 mm and if
more than 5 lesions are found.
(Choice D) Cutis Marmorata appears as a lace-like pattern on the skin in response to cold or stress. It
can persist in some diseases such as Down's syndrome and trisomy 18.
(Choice E) A salmon patch is a flat salmon-colored lesion commonly seen over the glabella, eyelids, and
neck. It is a vascular lesion that usually disappears in early childhood.
Educational Objective:
The characteristic description of a Mongolian spot is a well-demarcated, flat, blue/gray, lesion over the
sacral/presacral area that disappears in the first few years of life.

question:
A female infant is born full-term to a 24-year-old Caucasian primigravida. The delivery was uncomplicated.
The Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The prenatal course was complicated with
asymptomatic bacteriuria that was treated with an antibiotic. The mother took multivitamins during her last
trimester, occasionally took acetaminophen for back pain throughout the pregnancy, and denies smoking and
alcohol consumption. Physical examination of the infant reveals a blood-tinged vaginal discharge and
bilaterally enlarged mammary glands. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: D. Imaging studies to visualize adrenals
E. Imaging studies to visualize ovaries
explanation:
Mammary gland enlargement and non-purulent vaginal discharge are common findings in newborn
infants. These are benign, transitory events which represent the infant's physiologic target-organ response to
transplacentally acquired maternal hormones (estrogens). No work-up is necessary, and routine care should
be provided to the infant.
(Choice A) A buccal smear is helpful in diagnosing Turner's syndrome.
(Choices B and D) Urinary corticosteroid precursor measurement and imaging studies to visualize the
adrenals are used to diagnose congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
(Choices C and E) FSH/LH assay and imaging studies to visualize the ovaries are useful in patients with
hirsutism or primary amenorrhea.
Educational Objective:
Mammary gland enlargement and non-purulent vaginal discharge are common findings in newborn
infants. These are transitory physiologic events; therefore, such infants only require observation and routine
care.
*Extremely high yield question for the USMLE!!

question:
A 5-year-old fair-skinned, blue-eyed girl is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset
weakness on the left side of the body and slurred speech. She was playing with her toys just before the
incident. There is no history of trauma to the head. Her medical history is unremarkable. She is tall for her
age. The rest of her growth curve is below the 5th percentile. Her developmental milestones are delayed.
She has long, emaciated arms and legs, and arachnodactyly. Physical examination reveals brisk deep
tendon reflexes, positive Babinski sign on the left side, hyperlaxity of the skin and joints, and mild scoliosis.
What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
explanation:
This patient has homocystinuria, which is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from errors in
methionine metabolism secondary to cystathionine synthase deficiency. Her history is typical. She
was apparently normal at birth, and began to present with developmental delays thereafter. (Some infants
may present with failure to thrive.) More features appeared with time, such as skeletal abnormalities and
osteoporosis. Although some of her features are characteristic of Marfan's syndrome (i.e, tall stature, long
emaciated extremities, arachnodactyly, hyperlaxity of the skin and joints), her clinical presentation of a stroke
is highly indicative of homocystinuria. (Remember: Marfan's features + thromboembolic events = classic
homocystinuria) Patients with homocystinuria may have thromboembolic events at any age, due to the
pathologic changes in the vessel walls and increased adhesiveness of the platelets. Such events most
commonly involve the cerebral vessels. Furthermore, another differentiating factor is the type of
lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) that occurs with these diseases. In Marfan's syndrome, the lens is typically
dislocated upward, and in homocystinuria, it is dislocated downward. Other eye complications of
homocystinuria are cataract formation and retinal detachment. As in phenylketonuria, patients usually have a
fair complexion, but the musty odor is lacking.
Elevation of both homocysteine and methionine in body fluids confirm the diagnosis. The initial treatment is
administration of high doses of Vitamin B6. Restriction of methionine along with supplementation of cysteine
is used for patients not responsive to Vitamin B6 therapy.
(Choice A) Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism of phenylalanine, wherein phenylalanine
hydroxylase is the deficient enzyme. This deficiency results in the build-up of phenylalanine and its
metabolites (phenyl ketones) in the blood and body fluids. Its clinical features include mental retardation, fair
complexion, blue eyes, eczema and a musty body odor. Patients do not have a hypercoagulable state.
(Choice C) Krabbe's disease is a sphingolipidosis due to a deficiency in beta-galactosidase, which results in
a total absence of myelin. Clinical features include mental retardation, blindness, deafness, paralysis,
peripheral motor sensory neuropathy and seizures. Patients do not have a hypercoagulable state.
(Choice D) The body habitus is characteristic of Marfan's syndrome, but the fair complexion and the
presence of a thromboembolic accident point to homocystinuria. Remember that Marfan's patients do not
have mental retardation and thromboembolic events.
(Choice E) Tay Sach's disease is another sphingolipidosis due to beta-hexosaminidase A
deficiency. Clinical findings include mental retardation, blindness, cherry-red macula, weakness, and
seizures. Patients do not have a hypercoagulable state.
(Choice F) Although sickle cell anemia may cause thromboembolic events, the clinical picture is very
evocative of homocystinuria.
(Choice G) Fabry's disease is also a sphingolipidosis that results from a deficiency of alpha-
galactosidase. The classic clinical features include angiokeratomas, peripheral neuropathy, and
asymptomatic corneal dystrophy. Patients may develop kidney and heart failure, and thromboembolic events.
(Choice H) An isolated AV malformation would not explain the whole clinical picture.
Educational Objective:
Marfan's features + mental retardation + thromboembolic events + downward dislocation of the lens =
Homocystinuria. It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by cystathionine synthase
deficiency. Treatment mainly involves administration of high doses of Vit B6.
Know this!!

question:
A 6-year-old female child is brought to the emergency department due to fever, chills and abdominal pain.
She has been complaining of burning micturition and abdominal pain for the last 2 days. Her temperature is
102 F (38.9C), respirations are 20/min, pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Physical
examination reveals costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine analysis shows pyuria, significant bacteriuria,
WBC casts, positive nitrite, and esterase. What is the most likely cause of this condition in children?
explanation:
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is defined as the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the ureter and renal
pelvis. Normally, the ureter is attached to the bladder in an oblique fashion, leading to a flap-valve
mechanism that prevents reflux. When the submucosal portion of the ureter between the mucosa and
detrusor muscle is short or absent, reflux occurs. VUR is generally congenital, occurs in approximately 1%
of children, and is more common in girls. It is a risk factor for UTI as it facilitates the transport of bacteria
from bladder to the upper urinary tract; this explains why VUR is the most likely cause of acute UTI in
children. VUR is present in 35-40 % of children with UTI. The diagnosis is made with voiding
cystourethrogram (VCUG) followed by renal imaging.
(Choice B) Wilm's tumor is generally seen in children, but is not a common cause of acute UTI.
(Choice D) Ureteral duplication can lead to vesicoureteral reflux and acute UTI, but most of the vesicoureteral
reflux are congenital, familial, and due to the anomalous intravesical portion of the ureter.
(Choices A and E) Renal stones and hydronephrosis are not common in this age group.
Educational Objective:
Acute UTI in children is most commonly due to vesicoureteral reflux, which is mostly congenital and is seen
in 1 % of newborns.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling on his outstretched hand. On
examination, there is minimal swelling at the right elbow. The skin on the right forearm appears tense, and
severe pain is present. The brachial pulses are good bilaterally, and sensations are intact in both upper
limbs. X-rays of the right upper limb show a displaced anterior fat pad. Which of the following statements is
true about this condition?
options: A. The presence of brachial pulse on the right side rules out the possibility of vascular compromise
B. Fracture of forearm bones is responsible for the swelling
C. The treatment should consist of immediate cast placement
D. Suspect child abuse and report the case to child protection services
E. Forearm swelling is due to ischemia of the forearm soft tissues
explanation:
The clinical and x-ray findings suggest supracondylar fracture of the humerus causing Volkmann's ischemic
contracture.
(Choice A) Because of collateral flow, a brachial artery injury may be present despite normal distal pulses.
(Choice C) The condition is a type of compartment syndrome, and treatment should consist of immediate
compartment release fasciotomy to prevent further damage.
(Choice D) There are not enough clues to suspect child abuse.
(Choice B) Fractures of forearm bones may cause forearm swelling, but these will not demonstrate the
anterior fat pad sign on x-rays.
Educational Objective:
Displaced anterior fat pad is a radiographic sign of supracondylar fracture, which may be complicated by
Volkmann's ischemic contracture.

question:
An 8-week-old female infant is brought to the office by her Caucasian mother for a well-baby examination.
She was born at 34 weeks gestation, and weighed 2.9kg (6.5lb) at birth. She has been exclusively breastfed
since birth, and her growth and development are normal for her age. The physical examination is normal,
except for mild pallor. At this time, what is the most appropriate nutritional intervention for this patient?
options: C. Inclusion of vegetables in diet
D. Inclusion of fruit juices in diet
E. Introduce egg and meat in diet
explanation:
The presentation of this patient (e.g. premature, 8 weeks of age, pallor) is suggestive of mild anemia. This
condition usually presents at the second or third month of life, and the common symptoms and signs are
pallor, tachycardia, and tachypnea. In this case, although the infant may be getting iron via breastfeeding, iron
supplementation in the form of oral ferrous salts or iron-fortified milk formula is still warranted.
(Choices C and E) Solid foods such as vegetables, eggs and meat are usually introduced in the diet at
approximately 4 months of age.
(Choice D) Fruit juices are good sources of vitamins, however, these are also introduced in the diet at
approximately 5-7 months of age.
Educational Objective:
Iron supplementation in the form of oral ferrous salts or iron-fortified milk formula is warranted in premature
infants to prevent anemia of prematurity.

question:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to persistent leg pain. Over the last few months, he has been
constantly complaining of pain in his legs. The painful episodes occur only at night, and last a few hours
each. His mother has been treating him with over-the-counter medications. He is able to walk and run to
school without any complaints. He has no fever, chills and history of trauma. On examination, there is no
obvious trauma to his legs, and the limb exam is completely normal. His parents are very worried and ask
that you "do something." Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Growing pains are common in children between the ages of two and twelve. The pain is usually poorly
localized and common in the legs (usually below the knees and bilateral). It awakens the child at night and
responds to reassurance, massages or analgesics. In all cases, it resolves in the morning. The diagnosis of
growing pain is a diagnosis of exclusion. All the physical and laboratory findings are negative. X-rays are not
required if the physical exam is unremarkable. All such children are observed, and parents are assured that
this condition will resolve with time.
(Choice A) X-rays are indicated if any pathology is suspected. When a diagnosis of growing pains is made
and the physical exam is normal, x-rays are not warranted. The exam in these children is unremarkable and
there are no physical findings.
(Choice B) Bone scans are never used in the diagnosis of growing pains. Bone scans are generally used in
the diagnosis of metastatic bone disease or osteomyelitis. The occasional child with a bone tumor may
present with such a scenario, but the pain is localized to one leg.
(Choice C) Since the child has no obvious physical or laboratory findings, blood cultures are not
indicated. For bone pathology, blood cultures have very low diagnostic yield.
(Choice D) Psychiatric evaluation is not required for children with growing pains. All these children have
normal mental capacity and intellect.
Educational Objective:
Suspect growing bone pain in a child with nocturnal pain and no obvious physical or laboratory finding. The
treatment is reassurance.

question:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother. Two weeks ago, he developed a
low-grade fever followed by a persistent cough. He occasionally has severe paroxysms of cough that are
precipitated by eating and do not resolve with antitussive medications. On physical examination, extensive
subcutaneous emphysema over the anterior chest is noted. What is the most appropriate next step in the
management of this patient?
explanation:
Severe coughing paroxysms may result in subcutaneous emphysema, wherein air leaks from the chest wall
into the subcutaneous tissues due to the high intraalveolar pressure provoked by the cough. By a similar
process, pneumothorax can occur; therefore, in such patients (i.e. those with apparent subcutaneous
emphysema secondary to severe coughing paroxysms), chest x-rays must be obtained emergently to rule
out pneumothorax.
(Choice B) Cultures of the throat may be relevant in this case for diagnosis, but pneumothorax should still be
ruled out first.
(Choice C) An ear infection could have caused this child's condition via oropharyngeal transmission, but this
information is still not as important as the absence/presence of a pneumothorax.
(Choice D) In this child, there is no reason for a CT scan of the head since there are no neurologic findings.
(Choice E) Blood cultures are not warranted in this child. Throat cultures should be done first before blood
cultures.
Educational Objective:
In patients with apparent subcutaneous emphysema secondary to severe coughing paroxysms, chest x-rays
must be obtained first to rule out pneumothorax.

question:
The police bring a 14-year-old boy to the clinic after he was found setting fire to the neighbor's house. He has
been previously arrested and warned by the cops twice. The first time was 15 months ago for stealing his
neighbor's motorcycle. The second occasion was 6 months ago for a fight with his peers on the roadside.
His parents arrive and tell you that he has been behaving this way for the past 3 years, and often argues at
home. He steals money from them and tries to hurt the pets. Although they have not seen him using any
drugs, they suspect that his behavior could be due to drugs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conduct disorder is characterized by disruptive behavioral patterns that violate basic social norms for at least
one year in patients less than 18 years old. It includes aggressive behavior towards others or animals,
behaviors resulting in property damage, theft, or violations of societal rules. The patient in this case has had
all these typical symptoms for more than a year; hence, conduct disorder is the most likely diagnosis.
(Choice B) Antisocial personality disorder would be the diagnosis if the patient were more than 18 years
old. In conduct disorder, the outcome is most often antisocial personality disorder.
