(Choice C) Oppositional defiant disorder is also seen more commonly in late childhood and adolescence,
but is characterized by disruptive behavior such as negativity, hostility, and defiance.
(Choice D) Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is usually diagnosed before the patient is 7 years
old and characterized by impulsivity, inattention and hyperactivity. Conduct disorder is a common outcome of
ADHD.
(Choice E) Substance abuse is another very close differential diagnosis in an adolescent, but even though
the parents are suspicious, they have not seen him abusing drugs. At this point and based on the
characteristic history, the patient is more likely to have conduct disorder, rather than substance abuse;
however, it must be noted that conduct disorder is often associated with substance-related disorders and
school failures.
Educational Objective:
Conduct disorder is characterized by disruptive behavioral patterns that violate basic social norms for at
least one year in patients less than 18 years old.

question:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of seizures during class. His
teacher says that the seizure started suddenly, and he fell to the ground with sustained flexion of the arms
and extension of the legs, followed by clonic movements of the whole body. He has also been irritable lately,
and his school performance has declined. His parents arrive shortly and say that they recently noticed he
was lethargic and frequently complained of headaches, especially in the morning. His medical history is
unremarkable. Physical examination reveals decreased muscle strength of the left side of the body, with
brisk deep tendon reflexes in the left arm and leg. MRI of the head reveals a space-occupying lesion in the
right parietal lobe. What tumor is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
explanation:
The clinical presentation and MRI findings of this patient are suggestive of a central nervous system (CNS)
tumor. In the pediatric population, CNS tumors are the most common solid tumors and the second most
common malignancies (after leukemias). Approximately 60% of these tumors are infratentorial, 25% are
supratentorial, and 15% arise in the midline. Astrocytomas are the most common histologic type for both
supratentorial and infratentorial groups.
(Choice B) Medulloblastoma is the second most common tumor of the posterior fossa in
children. Approximately 90% of cases arise from the vermis.
(Choice C) Glioblastoma multiforme is a highly malignant astrocytic tumor. It is unlikely in this case because
it is usually seen in adults (elderly) patients.
(Choice D) Pinealoma develops in the dorsal aspect of the midbrain. Symptoms consist of endocrine
syndrome, intracranial hypertension, Parinaud's sign (paralysis of vertical gaze), and Collier's sign (retraction
of the eyelid).
(Choice E) Craniopharyngiomas arise in the sella turcica, and symptoms usually include visual field defects
and an endocrine syndrome. It is characterized by a cystic structure with calcifications.
Educational Objective:
In the pediatric population, infratentorial tumors are more common than supratentorial tumors, and benign
astrocytomas are the most common histologic type in both groups.

question:
A 7-year-old Caucasian boy is brought to the clinic due to malaise and headache for the past 2 weeks. He
was apparently normal until 3 weeks ago, when he went on a hiking trip with his family to Connecticut. His
father found a tick attached to his thigh; however, a red macule remains at the site where the tick was
attached. One week after the tick was removed, a red ring developed around the macule, and then the ring
appeared to grow larger by expanding outward leaving an area of central clearing. What is the most
appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
This patient's presentation is classic for erythema migrans, which is stage 1 or early-localized Lyme
disease. In children less then 9 years old, amoxicillin (50-mg/kg/day po divided tid for 21 days, maximum
dose 500 mg/dose) is the recommended treatment.
(Choice A) Doxycycline (100 mg po bid for 21 days) is the recommended treatment in children >= 9 years
old. Alternatives for those who cannot take amoxicillin or doxycycline include cefuroxime axetil or
erythromycin for 21 days.
(Choices C and D) Ceftriaxone or penicillin G for 14-21 days is recommended for Stage 3 Lyme disease,
which is a disseminated disease with neurological and/or cardiac manifestations. This patient does not have
any of these features.
Educational Objective:
Amoxicillin for 21days is the recommended treatment for erythema migrans or stage 1 Lyme disease in
children <9 years old.

question:
A child is brought to the physician for a routine visit. On examination, the child can name multiple items in the
examination room, and can also combine 2 words into a short sentence. His mother estimates that he
knows about 200 words. When his mother tries to help him onto the examination table, he says "me do it."
Although his mother seems to understand most of what he says, you can only understand about half of his
speech. Which of the following is the most likely age of this child?
explanation:
Language development begins in infancy and increases rapidly between the ages of one and four. A 24-
month-old child should have a vocabulary of about 150-300 words and be able to combine words into short
sentences. These children are in the process of learning pronouns, although they frequently use "me"
instead of "I". They are also learning prepositions. A stranger should be able to understand half of the child's
speech at this age.
(Choice A) A 12-month-old can usually say "mama", "dada", and one other word. They should also be able
to follow simple commands with gestures.
(Choice B) By 15 months, children can say "mama", "dada", and 3-5 other words. They can also
understand simple commands even without a gesture.
(Choice C) An 18-month-old typically has a vocabulary of approximately 5-20 words.
(Choice E) By 3 years of age, a child's vocabulary has usually increased to close to 1000 words, and about
75% of the child's speech can be understood by a stranger. In addition, they speak in 3-4 word sentences
and use pronouns correctly.
Educational objective:
A 2-year-old should have a vocabulary of several hundred words and be able to combine words into short
sentences. In addition, half of their speech should be understandable to a stranger.

question:
A 13-year-old female is brought to your office for evaluation of a limp. She has had mild left hip pain for
several weeks. After falling off her bicycle today, her mother noticed that she was limping and brought her
into your office. Her weight is 77.2 kg (170 lbs) and height is 165 cm (65 in). She walks with a limp to the
examination table. As she sits down, her left leg is rotated externally. There is decreased range of motion
and pain with internal rotation of her left hip. There is no leg length discrepancy. A lateral radiograph of her
hip is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
[Image showing SCFE radiograph was referenced here but not provided in text]
options: A. Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
explanation:
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a common hip disorder seen in adolescents. SCFE occurs
when the capital femoral epiphysis displaces from the acetabulum. Boys are affected more often than girls,
and the usual age of presentation is 10 to 16 years old. Obesity is a significant risk factor for the
development of SCFE, and additional risk factors include endocrine issues such as hypothyroidism,
panhypopituitarism, and growth hormone deficiency or supplementation. Children with endocrine issues in
particular are more likely to have bilateral disease and to present at an earlier age. Patients commonly
present with an insidious onset of knee or hip pain and a limp, usually without a history of
trauma. Sometimes, minor trauma can increase the pain and bring the patient to medical attention, similar to
this case. On examination, affected patients tend to hold the hip in passive external rotation and exhibit
decreased internal rotation, abduction, and flexion. Diagnosis is made with plain radiographs of the hip (AP
and frog leg lateral views), which show the posteriorly and inferiorly displaced femoral head. Treatment
consists of emergent orthopedic consultation and surgical fixation at the current degree of slippage to avoid
the risk of avascular necrosis.
(Choice A) Avascular necrosis of the femoral head can be a complication of SCFE because the displaced
femoral head can disrupt the blood supply. Avascular necrosis can also occur in Legg-Calve-Perthes
disease (Choice D), which is most commonly seen in younger children (ages 5-7) with idiopathic infarction
of the femoral head.
(Choice C) Femoral neck stress fractures occur most commonly in runners or other athletes doing
extensive training. Patients typically present with a gradual increase in hip pain, especially with activity. They
also have pain with passive range of motion of the hip, especially internal and external rotation.
(Choice E) Developmental hip dysplasia is caused by abnormal development of the hip in utero. It is usually
detected on the newborn physical exam, but can be diagnosed at a later age when a limp is noted. Leg
length discrepancy is present in developmental hip dysplasia and radiographs show a poorly formed femoral
head.
Educational objective:
Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is a common hip disorder seen in overweight adolescents.

question:
A one-month-old child is brought to the office due to persistent vomiting for the last six days. His mother
complains of increasing episodes of projectile vomiting. These episodes occur every time she attempts to
feed him, and have persisted despite changing formulas. On physical examination, peristaltic waves are
seen over the upper abdomen, and an olive-sized mass is palpated. Laboratory studies reveal a potassium
level of 3.0mEq/mL. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
options: D. Intravenous hydration and potassium replacement
explanation:
This case illustrates a typical patient with pyloric stenosis: a 4- to 6-week old male infant with projectile
vomiting that worsens over time. The vomitus usually consists of partially undigested food. The
pathognomonic finding of a palpable olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen is sufficient evidence to
warrant surgery, however, all infants must be well-hydrated and have normal or corrected electrolyte levels
prior to any surgery. This concept of pre-surgical stabilization has led to better post-operative results. In this
case, the patient should be admitted and given intravenous fluids with potassium. A nasogastric tube may be
required. Surgery is performed once the electrolyte levels normalize (after approximately 2-3 days).
(Choice A) In the past, whenever a surgical disorder was diagnosed in infants, the patient was rushed to the
operating room. This concept is now of historical interest. Surgery should never be undertaken in any infant
who needs resuscitation and replacement of electrolytes.
(Choice B) Medical treatment with metoclopramide (Reglan) has no role in the treatment of pyloric stenosis.
(Choice C) Pyloric stenosis should be corrected as soon as the infant's hydration status and electrolyte
levels are stabilized. Unlike surgical repair of umbilical hernias and asymptomatic atrial septal defects,
surgical repair of pyloric stenosis should not be delayed until school age.
(Choice E) Patients with pyloric stenosis are given nothing by mouth (NPO, nil per os) until after the surgery
is performed; however, simply avoiding milk products will not address the cause and treat the patient's
condition.
Educational Objective:
Pyloric stenosis is treated surgically; however, surgery should be undertaken only after the infant's hydration
status and electrolyte levels have been stabilized.

question:
A 3-year-old boy of African descent is brought to your office by his stepfather because of easy bruising. He
says that the child bruises easily even without trauma. The child started playing games by himself recently.
He has a past history of clavicular fracture, which the stepfather attributes to a fall down a set of stairs. The
history of the biological father is unknown. On examination, there is a right knee effusion with decreased
range of motion, and multiple soft tissue hematomas on the thigh. What is the most appropriate diagnostic
step in management?
options: C. Obtain prothrombin time and liver function tests
explanation:
This child's symptoms could be due to a bleeding disorder or to child abuse. This patient's symptoms are
most likely due to hemophilia because the presence of spontaneous hemarthrosis and soft tissue
hematomas are very unlikely with any other form of bleeding disorder, including Von Willebrand's disease;
therefore, the best next step is to get a factor VIII level.
(Choice A) Always rule out the medical causes before you think of child abuse in any patient.
(Choice B) Type 1 collagen assay is used to detect osteogenesis imperfecta. Multiple fractures with
different stages of healing are characteristic of this condition. The presence of one fracture with a history of a
fall doesn't signify osteogenesis imperfecta.
(Choices C and E) Obtaining only the bleeding time (platelet disorder) won't provide much
information. Furthermore, although all patients have their bleeding time, prothrombin time, and partial
thromboplastin time routinely measured before having a factor VIII assay, only a factor VIII assay will yield the
diagnosis in this case.
Educational Objective:
Spontaneous hemarthrosis raises the suspicion for hemophilia, for which factor VIII assay is
diagnostic. Prolonged PTT, normal prothrombin time, normal bleeding time, normal fibrinogen level and low
serum factor VIII activity are the typical lab findings. The standard treatment for hemophilia is to replace the
factor VIII. However, mild hemophilia may be treated with desmopressin (DDAVP), which causes release of
factor VIII from the endothelial cells.

question:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the office for a follow-up visit. She has been previously diagnosed with
vesicoureteral reflux, and has had multiple episodes of acute urinary tract infections in the past. Intravenous
pyelography (performed on her last visit) reveals bilateral focal parenchymal scarring and blunted calyces.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The history (i.e, recurrent UTI secondary to reflux) and IVP findings of this girl are highly suggestive of
chronic pyelonephritis. Chronic pyelonephritis is seen on IVP as blunting of calices (calyceal clubbing) and
focal parenchymal scarring.
(Choice A) Hydronephrosis is seen on IVP as dilation of the collecting system including the calyces, pelvis
and ureter, depending on the level of obstruction.
(Choice B) Ureteropelvic obstruction would also lead to hydronephrotic changes in the kidney with IVP
showing the level of obstruction as a constriction in the flow of dye.
(Choice D) Nephrosclerosis is a histological diagnosis, and cannot be diagnosed from IVP.
Educational Objective:
Chronic pyelonephritis is characterized by focal parenchymal scarring and blunting of calices on IVP.

question:
A 3-year-old African-American female is brought to the office due to a swelling in her abdomen. According to
her parents, this swelling was first noted when she was 3 months old, and has been increasing in size over
the past 6 months. It is more pronounced during crying and coughing. Examination reveals a soft swelling of
the umbilical region that is 3 cm in diameter and covered by skin. It can be easily reduced through the fibrous
ring at the umbilicus. The child is afebrile and in good health. What is the most likely diagnosis and best
course of action for this patient?
options: A. Umbilical hernia, refer to pediatric surgeon for operative management.
B. Umbilical hernia, observe for spontaneous resolution.
C. Congenital omphalocele, refer to pediatric surgeon.
explanation:
Umbilical hernia is due to an imperfect closure or weakness of the umbilical ring. It is especially common in
low birth weight, female, and black infants. It appears as a soft swelling covered by skin that protrudes during
crying, coughing or straining, and can be reduced easily through the fibrous ring at the umbilicus. The hernia
consists of omentum or portions of the small intestine.
Most umbilical hernias disappear spontaneously by 1 year of age. Surgery is advised if the hernia persists to
the age of 3-4 years, exceeds 2 cm in diameter, causes symptoms, becomes strangulated, or progressively
enlarges after the age of 1 to 2 years.
(Choice B) In this case, three of the above indications for surgery are present; hence, observation for
spontaneous resolution is not the best management option.
(Choice C) An omphalocele is a herniation or protrusion of abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical
cord, and is usually diagnosed at birth. In contrast to the more common umbilical hernia, the sac is covered
with peritoneum without overlying skin. Immediate surgical repair before infections take place is essential for
survival. The presence of skin covering the swelling and the age of presentation in this patient point towards
the diagnosis of umbilical hernia.
(Choice D) Umbilical polyp is a rare anomaly resulting from persistence of all, or part, of the
omphalomesenteric duct or urachus. The tissue of the polyp is firm and resistant, bright red, and has a
mucoid secretion. Treatment is surgical excision of the entire omphalomesenteric or urachal remnant.
(Choice E) Gastroschisis is diagnosed at birth by protrusion of bright red intestines to the right side of the
umbilicus. There is no covering of the intestines, and the umbilicus is normal. It is a surgical emergency.
Educational Objective:
Surgery is advised if an umbilical hernia persists to the age of 3-4 years, exceeds 2 cm in diameter, causes
symptoms, becomes strangulated, or enlarges progressively after the age of 1 to 2 years.

question:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office due to a sudden onset of petechiae and epistaxis. Three weeks ago,
he had an upper respiratory tract infection which resolved uneventfully. Physical examination shows a few
petechiae over the trunk and extremities, but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show:
Hb                            13.5g/dL
WBC                        7,000/mm3
Differential count           normal
Platelets                     60,000/mm3
What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
Immune thrombocytopenia usually occurs in children between 2 and 5 years of age. The pathogenesis
involves antibodies that bind to platelets, and subsequent destruction of these complexes in the spleen. The
condition is usually preceded by a viral infection and presents with purpura, petechiae, hematuria or Gl
bleeding. There is no adenopathy. Laboratory studies usually show no abnormalities, except
thrombocytopenia. The course is self-limited, and spontaneous recovery occurs in the majority of
patients. There is some controversy regarding the treatment, but in general, corticosteroids are the drugs of
choice in all age groups for thrombocytopenia less than 30,000/mm3, and/or for severe symptoms. Patients
with a platelet count of more than 30,000/mm3 usually have very few symptoms and do not require treatment.
(Choice A) Immune thrombocytopenia is usually self-limited, and recovery occurs in the majority of
patients. Platelet transfusion is very rarely indicated, as it generally results in only further destruction of the
platelets. The few indications of platelet transfusion include severe cases with active bleeding or intracranial
bleeding.
(Choice B) IV antibiotics are not indicated in immune thrombocytopenia, as the condition is not related to a
bacterial infection.
(Choice D) When there is life-threatening bleeding, the spleen may need to be removed. The spleen is the
site of destruction of the platelets and by excising it, the platelets are spared. It is rarely needed, but can be a
life-saving measure.
(Choice E) Rarely, if the recovery is delayed and the immune attacks on the platelets continue, some may
choose to administer prednisone or immunoglobulin to these patients. This is more common in the
adult type of immune thrombocytopenia.
Educational Objective:
Suspect immune thrombocytopenia in children who develop isolated thrombocytopenia after a
viral infection. Immune thrombocytopenia is a relatively benign condition. There is some controversy
regarding the treatment, but in general, corticosteroids are the drugs of choice in all age groups for
thrombocytopenia less than 30,000/mm3, and/or for severe symptoms.

question:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of "possible developmental delay." His birth history
and medical histories are normal. His family history is unremarkable. He has a 9-year-old brother, who is in
good health. Physical examination reveals tall stature for age, long arms and legs with diminished
subcutaneous fat, long thin fingers, long face with crowded teeth, and prominent sternum. Hypermobility of
the joints, hyperelasticity of the skin with diminished recoil, and hypotonia are noted. Cardiovascular
examination reveals a diastolic murmur on the aortic area and along the left sternal border. Ophthalmologic
examination reveals iridodonesis and upward dislocation of the lens. What is the most likely etiology of his
condition?
options: A. Mutations of the fibrillin-1 gene
explanation:
This patient's physical appearance (i.e, tall stature for age, long arms and legs with diminished
subcutaneous fat, long thin fingers, long face with crowded teeth, prominent sternum) is very characteristic
for Marfan's syndrome. His physical findings (i.e., hypermobility of the joints, hyperelastic skin with
diminished recoil, hypotonia, diastolic murmur, iridodonesis, lens dislocation) are classic for the
disease. Iridodonesis is a rapid contraction and dilation of the iris, and results from dislocation of the lens
(ectopia lentis). The diastolic murmur has most likely resulted from aortic root dilation, which is a common
complication. Other manifestations of the disease include myopia, blue sclera, mitral valve prolapse, and
dural ectasia. The latter is defined as progressive ectasia of the dura and neural foramina, and erosion of the
vertebral bone resulting consequently in enlargement of the spinal canal. In this case, it is possible to wrongly
attribute the hypotonia and articular hypermobility to a developmental delay, but the clinical picture of Marfan's
syndrome is very characteristic, even without a positive family history. Although Marfan's syndrome is
an autosomal dominant disorder that results from mutations of the fibrillin-1 gene, up to 30% of the cases
may be sporadic.
(Choice B) The deformities in rickets (vitamin D-deficiency) are different from those found in Marfan's
syndrome. Such deformities include bowed legs, costochondral beading, craniotabes, and bossing of the
skull.
(Choice C) Fetal alcohol syndrome is characterized by microcephaly, mid face hypoplasia, flattened
philtrum, IUGR and mental retardation. Patients with Marfan's syndrome have normal intelligence.
(Choice D) Edward's syndrome, or trisomy 18, presents with mental retardation, micrognathia, low-set ears,
rocker bottom feet, prominent occiput, and clenched hands. (They do not survive this long)
(Choice E) Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from cystathionine synthase
deficiency, an enzyme involved in the metabolism of methionine. These patients share many features of
Marfan's syndrome, but they usually have a fair complexion, thromboembolic events and osteoporosis. The
other main differentiating feature is the type of lens dislocation. In Marfan's syndrome, the lens is typically
dislocated upward, whereas in homocystinuria it is dislocated downward.
(Choice F) Congenital contractural arachnodactyly (CCA) is an autosomal dominant condition that presents
with tall stature, arachnodactyly, and multiple contractures involving large joints. Marfan's patients do not
have joint contractures. Furthermore, ocular and cardiovascular symptoms are not present in CCA.
(Choice G) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a disorder of collagen structure, which may also have hypermobile
joints; however, it also results in easy bruising, poor wound healing and soft, velvety, and hyperelastic
skin. Severe complications such as organ rupture and severe hemorrhage may occur.
Educational Objective:
MSF is an autosomal dominant disorder that results from the mutations of the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene. It
presents with tall stature, long and emaciated extremities, arachnodactyly, hypermobility of the joints, upward
lens dislocation, and aortic root dilation.
Know this!!

question:
A 6-day-old female neonate is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of jaundice. She was born to a
17-year-old German mother at 39 weeks gestation. Her mother's blood type is B+, and was treated for
newborn jaundice due to presumed ABO incompatibility. Her other family members also had neonatal
jaundice. The infant's vital signs are normal. On examination, she is visibly jaundiced, and her spleen tip is
palpable. Her total bilirubin level is 25mg/dL and direct bilirubin level is 0.4mg/dL. Her hemoglobin was
initially 15.7g/dL, but is now 10.7g/dL. Her reticulocyte count is 4% and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. The
peripheral smear shows moderate schistocytes with burr cells and moderate spherocytes. Her blood type is
B+ and Coombs' test is negative. Her stools are negative for occult blood. Her mother's incubated red cell
osmotic fragility study is abnormal. What is the most likely cause of this neonate's symptoms?
options: A. Normal physiologic changes occurring in red cells in the neonatal period
D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to warm antibodies
E. Isoimmune hemolytic disease of the newborn, due to ABO incompatibility
explanation:
A positive osmotic fragility test indicates a hemolytic disease, and confirms the diagnosis of hereditary
spherocytosis, which is a common cause of hemolysis and hemolytic anemia in the newborn. The other
indicators of hemolysis include reticulocytosis and hyperbilirubinemia. The peripheral smear may reveal
anisocytosis and polychromatophilic reticulocytes and spherocytes. The typical patient is illustrated in this
case (i.e, jaundiced infant of Northern European descent with anemia). Severe anemia and
hyperbilirubinemia may require phototherapy or exchange transfusions.
(Choice A) The normal physiologic hematologic changes that occur in the neonatal period include:
(1) switching from fetal to adult hemoglobin production, (2) a 30% drop in hemoglobin, and (3) a fall in mean
red cell volume (MCV). Changes involving membrane pliability and intracellular enzyme levels also occur. In
this case, the drop in the patient's hemoglobin is more than 30 %, and her level of hyperbilirubinemia is
pathologic.
(Choice C) Hereditary elliptocytosis is a rare disorder that is characterized by elongated red blood
cells. Microcytes, spherocytes, and other poikilocytes may also be seen.
(Choice D) Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is confirmed by a positive Coombs’ test, and is caused by warm
antibodies directed against the red blood cells. The typical patient is a child aged 2 to 12 years, and the
anemia is usually acute and transient, lasting 3-6 months. It is frequently preceded by an infection, usually
respiratory. Spherocytosis and polychromasia may occur.
(Choice E) Isoimmune hemolytic disease of the newborn (particularly due to ABO incompatibility) may also
present with spherocytosis, and the direct Coomb's test is used to distinguish between these two. The
detection of antibody on the infant's red blood cells (positive Coomb's test) establishes the diagnosis of
immune hemolysis.
Educational Objective:
A positive Coombs’ test points towards autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and a positive osmotic fragility test
points towards hereditary spherocytosis.

question:
Parents bring their 7-year-old girl to the hospital after having fever for the last 6 days. The mother is worried
about her eyes which have become red, and thinks that something has spilled in them. On physical
examination her vitals are, Temperature: 39.4C(103F); PR: 120/min, BP: 110/80; RR: 24/min. Significant
examination findings include injected pharynx, erythematous palms and a left sided cervical lymph node
enlargement (1.7 cm). The trunk showed erythematous, blanching rash with no rash over the face. Labs
revealed:
ESR                               38mm/h
Hct                                 46%
WBCs                             12,000/mm3
Platelets                           500,000/mm3
Urine analysis:
Protein                             Positive
WBCs                             7/hpf
RBCs                              Negative
WBC & RBC Casts               Negative
What is most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
The patient most probably has Kawasaki's disease, the treatment of which consists of aspirin and IV
immunoglobulins. It is the standard of care to start therapy right after making the clinical diagnosis of
Kawasaki's disease. Aspirin is useful because of its antiplatelet and anti-inflammatory action. This is one of
the conditions in which aspirin is recommended in children despite concerns about Reye's syndrome.
Influenza vaccination is recommended in patients with Kawasaki's disease taking life long aspirin therapy.
Diagnosis of Kawasaki's disease doesn't require lymph node biopsy, throat culture or skin biopsy.
Antibiotics and steroids have no role in the management of Kawasaki's disease. Coronary artery aneurysm
formation, one of the complication of this disease, may in fact be enhanced by the use of steroids.
Educational Objective:
The treatment of Kawasaki's disease consists of aspirin and IV immunoglobulins.

question:
A 2-year-old child is brought by an anxious mother to the emergency department because of difficulty in
breathing for the past 12 hours. The child has a history of runny nose that started 3 days ago. He suddenly
developed a progressively increasing difficulty in breathing. The mother reports that the child "sounds like a
barking dog when he coughs." The child's temperature is 37.7C(99.8F), respirations are 30/min, blood
pressure is 80/60mm Hg, and pulse rate is 104/min. He is coughing and using his accessory muscles of
respiration. His oxygen saturation is 98% on 2L of oxygen. He is diagnosed with
laryngotracheobronchitits, started on humidified oxygen, and kept in an upright position. After 20
minutes, he becomes more irritable, his oxygen saturation drops to 82%, respirations increase to 40/min,
and pulse increases to 120/min. His blood pressure and temperature are unchanged. What is the most
appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: B. Take the patient to the operating room
D. Intubate the patient in the emergency room
explanation:
Always give a trial of epinephrine in cases of croup before intubation. Controlled trials have shown that a trial
of racemic epinephrine should precede any invasive procedure in cases of croup, as this decreases the need
for intubation. Epinephrine acts by its alpha-adrenergic and beta-adrenergic effects. In asthma, the alpha-
adrenergic effect is beneficial by reducing bronchial secretions and mucosal edema. This similar process is
thought to help patients with croup. In addition, the beta-adrenergic effect helps croup patients who are also
wheezing by promoting smooth muscle relaxation.
Educational Objective:
Racemic epinephrine decreases the need for intubation in patients with croup and should always be tried
before any invasive procedure.

question:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because he was sent home by the school nurse. The
nurse claims to have heard a murmur in his chest. The child has always been healthy, and has never had
any shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness or any other illnesses. On examination, the child appears
alert, and his vital signs are stable. Auscultation of the chest reveals a grade-2 systolic ejection murmur at
the left sternal border, but no other extra sounds. The murmur changes with position. What is the best next
step in the management of this patient?
explanation:
It has been estimated that fifty to eighty percent of children will have audible murmurs at some point in their
lives; thus, it is very important to distinguish a benign (innocent) murmur from a pathologic murmur. Most
murmurs are functional (innocent) and without any associated structural abnormalities. An innocent murmur
has a systolic ejection quality, is less than III/VI in grade, and varies with position; there are usually no other
extra sounds. The majority of children with innocent murmurs are asymptomatic, and the murmur usually
disappears as the child grows; therefore, observation of such patients is all that is necessary in their
management.
(Choice A) Electrocardiogram is not routinely used in the evaluation of murmurs, although there are current
studies that support this practice.
(Choice B) Pathological murmurs may indicate or lead to congenital heart disease, and are very likely when
the patient has any of the following:
Symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, syncope, and dizziness, etc.
Murmur intensity grade 3 or higher
Abnormal S2
Pansystolic murmur
Murmur loudest at upper left sternal border
Absent or diminished femoral pulses
Murmur's quality is unchanged with position
When a murmur with any of these features is detected, investigations are required. An echocardiogram is
usually the first step in the evaluation of pathologic murmurs. Echocardiography is diagnostic for a number of
valvular and congenital heart diseases in children.
(Choice C) A Holter monitor is used for outpatient detection of arrhythmias. A Holter monitor is a portable
device that is worn by the patient for several days as it records the heart rate. After a few days, the
recordings are analyzed to determine if there were any arrhythmias.
(Choice E) A cardiology evaluation is not required for benign murmurs of childhood. If there is any suspicion
of pathology, a cardiology consult is required.
(Choice F) Blood cultures are obtained when there is a suspicion for infective endocarditis (IE). This patient
has no symptoms or signs suggestive of IE.
Educational Objective:
Most cardiac murmurs in childhood are benign and require only observation. Know the following features of a
benign murmur:
Asymptomatic patient
Murmur intensity grade 2 or less
Normal S2
No audible clicks
Normal pulses
No other abnormalities

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because he has not started to walk yet. His birth
history is significant for prolonged labor, and his APGAR scores at 1 and 5 minutes were 3 and 5,
respectively. His older brother is 4 years old, and has a normal developmental history. On examination, the
child has hypotonia, learning disabilities and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes. What is the most likely cause
for the child's delayed milestones?
explanation:
The clinical findings of hypotonia, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes, learning disabilities, along with an
intrapartum history of prolonged labor and low APGAR scores at birth, point towards the diagnosis of cerebral
palsy. Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive disorder characterized by impaired motor functioning. The most
common cause is cerebral anoxia.
(Choice D) Friedreich's ataxia is characterized by gait disturbances, pes cavus, ataxia and absent ankle
jerks.
(Choice E) Infantile spinal muscular atrophy, also known as Werdnig-Hoffman's syndrome, is characterized
by proximal and distal hypotonia since birth, normal social and language skills, and tongue fibrillations.
(Choice C) Congenital muscular dystrophies are characterized by gait ataxia, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy and
calf pseudohypertrophy.
(Choice B) Congenital infection is very unlikely in the given clinical setting.
Educational Objective:
Cerebral anoxia is the most common cause of cerebral palsy.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a cough and a "whistling" sound with
breathing. Two days ago, he developed rhinorrhea, fever, a hoarse cry and a progressively worsening, harsh,
"barky" cough. His immunizations are up-to-date. His 6-year-old brother also has cold symptoms. His
temperature is 37.5C (99.5F), pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 38/min. On examination, he is alert, in
mild respiratory distress, has a dry barking cough, hoarse cry, and some clear mucoid rhinorrhea. His
pharynx is slightly injected, but without enlargement or asymmetry. The lungs are clear on auscultation.
Lateral neck x-rays reveal a mildly narrowed subglottic region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Croup, also known as laryngotracheitis or laryngotracheobronchitis (LTB), is characterized by laryngeal
inflammation that results in hoarseness, a barking cough, and varying degrees of respiratory distress over
time. The typical patient is less than 3 years of age, and the most common causative agent is Parainfluenza
virus. Croup is usually a clinical diagnosis. Lateral neck x-rays show subglottic narrowing.
(Choice A) Epiglottitis is seen in older children. Furthermore, its presentation is different. The cough is not
"croupy”, and the patient appears more toxic, with high-grade fever, tachypnea and tachycardia. Stridor
and excessive drooling are often found. The three characteristic findings on lateral neck x-rays are: swollen
epiglottis (thumb sign), thickened aryepiglottic folds, and obliteration of the vallecula.
(Choice C) Bacterial laryngotracheobronchopneumonitis is characterized by signs of lower respiratory
involvement, such as wheezing and interstitial changes on chest x-rays. Hypoxia secondary to the lower
airway disease often occurs.
(Choice D) Foreign body aspiration should be considered in cases of sudden onset stridor without a fever.
(Choice E) Although laryngeal diphtheria is rare, it should still be considered because it sometimes presents
with a croup-like syndrome, known as membranous croup. In this case, however, the patient's immunization
history rules out this diagnosis.
Educational Objective:
Croup is caused by Parainfluenza virus and commonly presents in children younger than 3 years with
hoarseness, a barking cough, and varying degrees of respiratory distress.

question:
A 6-month-old girl is brought to the office by her mother with complaints of irritability and listlessness. The
mother is also concerned because the child cannot crawl and roll over anymore (she was able to do these
things a few weeks ago). On examination, the child has hypotonia, hepatosplenomegaly, cervical
lymphadenopathy and a protruding belly. On retinal examination, the child has a cherry red macula. What is
the most likely cause for the regression of this child's developmental milestones?
options: A. Sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of hexosaminidase A
B. Sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of sphingomyelinase
C. Sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of glucocerebrosidase
D. Sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of galactocerebrosidase
explanation:
This child has regression of milestones associated with physical findings such as hypotonia,
hepatosplenomegaly, cervical lymphadenopathy, protruding abdomen and ‘cherry red spot’ on retinal
examination. This constellation of findings fits the description of Niemann-Pick's disease, which is a
sphingolipidosis due to a deficiency in sphingomyelinase. Sphingomyelin (ceramide phosphorylcholine)
accumulates in the reticuloendothelial cells of liver, spleen, bone marrow and brain.
(Choice A) Sphingolipidosis due to a deficiency in hexosaminidase A is known as Tay-Sachs’ disease. It is
characterized by hyperacusis, mental retardation, seizures, cherry red macula, but not hepatosplenomegaly
or cervical lymphadenopathy.
(Choice C) Sphingolipidosis due to a deficiency in glucocerebrosidase is known as Gaucher's disease. It is
characterized by hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, leucopoenia and thrombocytopenia, but not cherry red
macula.
(Choice D) Sphingolipidosis due to a deficiency in galactocerebrosidase is known as Krabbe's disease. It is
characterized by hyperacusis, irritability and seizures.
(Choice E) Mucopolysaccharidoses are characterized by coarse facial features, hydrocephalus and
umbilical hernia.
Educational Objective:
Deficiency of sphingomyelinase causes Niemann-Pick's disease, which is characterized by cherry red
macula, protruding abdomen, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and regression of developmental
milestones.

question:
An obese Caucasian father brings his 10-year-old obese son to your office. The father states that he was
recently diagnosed with high cholesterol levels and coronary artery disease. Even though his son is
asymptomatic, he is worried about the obesity. Which of the following best explains the next best step in
management?
options: A. Get a fasting lipid profile
B. Get a screening test for total cholesterol level
C. Advise parents to start him on a low cholesterol diet
D. Evaluate him for coronary artery disease
E. Advise parents to start him on a regular physical exercise schedule.
explanation:
The Expert Panel on Blood Cholesterol Levels in Children and Adolescents of the National Cholesterol
Education Program and the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Nutrition have recommended
that children with a parental history of elevated total cholesterol levels (>=240mg/dL), or risk factors for
coronary heart disease should have a screening total cholesterol level.
(Choice A) A fasting lipid profile is recommended if the total cholesterol level is greater than 200mg/dL. It is
usually not the first step in evaluating an asymptomatic patient.
(Choices C and E) Advising the parents to start the kid on low cholesterol diet or an exercise therapy,
however helpful it may be, is not the next best step here.
(Choice D) Evaluation for coronary heart disease is not needed in this asymptomatic patient, unless other
risk factors such as hypercholesterolemia are present.
Educational objective:
Children with a parental history of elevated total cholesterol levels (>=240 mg/dL), or risk factors for coronary
artery disease should get a screening test for total cholesterol level.

question:
An 8-year-old African American child is brought to the office for the evaluation of a 1-day history of fever and
back pain. He has sickle cell disease, and has had 5 hospitalizations for similar painful crises. His laboratory
report shows normocytic anemia, reticulocytosis and leukocytosis. What finding is most likely to be present
on this patient's peripheral smear?
explanation:
Sickle cell patients usually have infarcted spleens by the first 18 to 36 months of life. Repeated
microinfarctions from clumping of sickle cells can destroy tissues, thereby leading to microvascular beds that
promote sickling. The peripheral smear characteristically reveals Howell-Jolly bodies. These bodies are
nuclear remnants of red blood cells which are generally removed by a functional spleen; therefore, their
presence suggests splenectomy or functional asplenia. Functional asplenia renders a patient susceptible
to infections, particularly from capsulated organisms such as pneumococci.
In this case, the patient has several years history of sickle cell disease and multiple, previous, similar, painful
crises. By this time, these repetitive occlusive events must have already damaged his spleen, leading to
functional asplenia. Howell Jolly bodies are most likely to be seen in his peripheral smear.
(Choices A and D) Heinz bodies are aggregates of denatured hemoglobin, and are commonly seen in
patients with hemolysis due to G6PD deficiency and thalassemia. When phagocytes extract this rigid
precipitate, they form characteristic bite cells.
(Choice B) Helmet cells are fragmented red blood cells. Their presence is suggestive of traumatic hemolytic
conditions such as DIC, HUS and TTP.
(Choice E) Basophilic stippling are ribosomal precipitates which appear as blue granules of various sizes
dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell. These are often seen with thalassemias, as well as lead
or heavy metal poisoning.
Educational Objective:
Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants of the red blood cells which are generally removed by a functional
spleen; therefore, their presence in a peripheral smear suggests functional asplenia in sickle cell patients.

question:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician's office by her mother due to recurrent, prolonged episodes of
nausea and severe vomiting for the past 4 days. According to the mother, the vomiting starts in the early
morning and recur 7 to 8 times daily. The child denies any headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, chest pain or
respiratory distress. She has had two similar episodes of vomiting and nausea in the past year, which
resolved spontaneously. The mother has a history of migraines. On examination, the child is afebrile and
has pallor with signs of mild dehydration. The abdomen is soft and non-tender to palpation. What is the most
likely cause of this child's symptoms?
explanation:
Recurrent self-limiting episodes of vomiting and nausea in children in the absence of any
apparent cause suggest the diagnosis of cyclical vomiting. The etiology of this condition is unclear;
however, its incidence is high in children whose parents have a history of migraine
headaches. Complications that may arise from the condition are anemia and dehydration. Treatment
consists of anti-emetics and reassurance of the parents.
(Choice E) Although migraine headaches have a higher incidence in persons with a positive family history, it
is unlikely in the absence of headaches.
(Choice A) Gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with regurgitation after feeding and failure to thrive.
(Choice C) Mesenteric adenitis presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, abdominal guarding and
tenderness.
(Choice B) The history of recurrent self-limiting episodes of vomiting and nausea, in the absence of other
complaints such as abdominal pain, diarrhea or fever, makes the diagnosis of gastroenteritis unlikely.
Educational Objective:
Recurrent self-limiting episodes of vomiting and nausea in children, in the absence of any apparent cause,
suggest the diagnosis of cyclical vomiting.

question:
An 11-month-old male infant is brought to the office for a well-baby examination. He was born at term and
weighed 3.7kg (8lb) at birth. His mother's work is "full time" so he is mostly taken care of by his
grandmother. His mother is concerned that he doesn't get to go outdoors since his grandmother has
osteoarthritis and her outdoor activity is limited. Physical examination reveals widely open fontanels and a
ping-pong-ball sensation on pressing firmly over the occiput. There are rounded enlargements on the
costochondral junctions, and thickening of the wrists and ankles. A horizontal depression is seen along the
lower border of the chest. X-ray reveals cupping and fraying of the distal ends of the radius and ulna. What
is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The history, physical and radiologic findings of this infant are diagnostic for rickets. This condition usually
presents after several months of being Vitamin D-deficient. The typical patients are low-birth weight infants,
unsupplemented dark-skinned infants, infants with inadequate sun exposure, and solely breastfed infants.
Common early manifestations are craniotabes (ping-pong ball sensation over the occiput or posterior parietal
bones), rachitic rosary (enlargement of the costochondral junctions), and thickening of the wrists and ankles.
Other characteristic findings are Harrison groove (horizontal depression on lower border of chest) and a large
anterior fontanelle. The diagnosis can be confirmed by obtaining the serum calcifediol level (decreased),
alkaline phosphatase level (increased), and observing the characteristic radiologic changes (cupping and
fraying of the distal ends of long bones, and double contour along the lateral outline of the radius). Treatment
includes oral Vitamin D administration and adequate sunlight (or artificial light) exposure. The current
recommendation to prevent rickets is oral Vitamin D supplementation, beginning during the first 2 months of
life and continuing until early adolescence.
(Choice A) Scurvy is commonly seen in 6 to 24-month-old infants with a characteristic history of Vitamin C
deficiency. Clinical manifestations are general tenderness, pseudoparalysis (frog position), bluish-purple
and spongy/swollen gums over the upper incisors, and depression of the sternum. A rosary similar to
rickets may be observed, but the angulation of the beads in patients with scurvy is usually sharper than in
those with rickets. The diagnosis is confirmed radiologically (pencil-point thinness of the long bones’ cortex,
and sharply outlined epiphyseal ends).
(Choice C) Nonrachitic craniotabes is unlikely in this patient because this condition usually presents in the
immediate postnatal period, and disappears before rachitic softening of the skull occurs during the 2nd-4th
months of life.
(Choice D) Patients with chondrodystrophy may also manifest with "rosary"; however, radiologic findings will
show irregular, concave outlines of the distal ends of the bones. Chondrodystrophy is therefore a less likely
diagnosis in this patient.
Educational Objective:
Vitamin D deficiency rickets presents with craniotabes, rachitic rosary, Harrison groove, large anterior
fontanelle, and thickening of the lower end of the long bones. The typical patients are low-birth weight infants,
unsupplemented dark-skinned infants, infants with inadequate sun exposure, and breastfed infants. The
typical pathology is - defective mineralization of growing bone or osteoid tissue.

question:
A father brings his 18-month-old daughter to the office for the evaluation of fever for the past 10 days. The
father, who works as a phlebotomist, says that the temperature seems higher in the morning and again at
night, often reaching 40.5C(105F), and is sometimes associated with shaking chills. He remembers that the
child developed severe respiratory distress and skin rash when treated with penicillin in the past. He has
heard about the development of 'liver toxicities’ in children treated with aspirin, and he is interested in knowing
everything about his daughter's condition. On examination, the child is in no acute distress. Her temperature
is 39.4C(103F), pulse rate is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Her sclerae are anicteric. There
is bulbar conjunctival injection, and the oropharynx shows diffuse mucosal injection with fissuring and
crusting of the lips. There are numerous hyperemic macules over her entire body, and her palms appear
edematous. Based on the above description, which of the following is the most accurate statement?
options: A. Latex agglutination test is more accurate than streptococcal throat test in determining the etiology of this condition
B. Immediate desensitization & treatment with penicillin IV will prevent further renal complications
C. Thrombocytopenia is an important marker in the second week of this illness
D. Acetaminophen is the drug of choice for alleviation of high temperatures in this child
E. She needs to be hospitalized and treated with intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and aspirin
explanation:
The case in question satisfies the criteria of Kawasaki's disease, which are:
1. Fever for >= 5 days, and
2. Four of the following symptoms:
Bulbar conjunctival injection
Desquamation of the finger and toe tips, indurative edema
Erythema, fissuring, and crusting of the lips, strawberry tongue, and diffuse mucosal injection
of the oropharynx
Morbilliform truncal exanthem
Cervical lymphadenopathy
Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome is one of the most common causes of
generalized vasculitis in children. It is usually self-limited, although it can be fatal because of giant aneurysm
formation, thrombosis or rupture of the coronary arteries, leading to myocardial infarction. 2D
echocardiography is used to assess cardiac function and coronary vasculature. A baseline
echocardiography is to be performed within 7 days of the disease onset, then repeated 6 to 8 weeks later.
(Choice A) The most common condition with which Kawasaki's disease is confused is scarlet fever;
however, scarlet fever will have a positive streptococcal throat test and normal-appearing lips, as opposed to
negative streptococcal throat test and inflamed lips in Kawasaki's disease. Latex agglutination test is more
rapid but less accurate in the diagnosis of scarlet fever.
(Choice B) The treatment of choice for scarlet fever is a ten-day course of penicillin V; however, in
penicillin-allergic patients, erythromycin or clindamycin can be used. Treatment of scarlet fever with penicillin
doesn't prevent post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
(Choice C) The laboratory abnormalities associated with Kawasaki's disease are increased acute phase
reactants such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein, leukocytosis,
normochromic-normocytic anemia, and thrombocytosis (not thrombocytopenia). Thrombocytosis is a non-specific finding and
does not characterize this illness.
(Choice D) Fever in Kawasaki's disease poorly responds to acetaminophen. All patients with suspected
Kawasaki disease should be hospitalized and treated with intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and high-dose
aspirin. The mainstays of systemic treatment of Kawasaki's disease are intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
and aspirin. Aspirin is useful for fever and arthritis. IVIG has been shown to reduce the incidence of coronary
artery aneurysms and other complications. If untreated, up to 25 percent of these patients may develop
coronary artery aneurysms.
Educational Objective:
Although, it is typically a self-limited condition, all patients with suspected Kawasaki disease should be
hospitalized and treated with intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin. If untreated, up to 25
percent of these patients may develop coronary artery aneurysms.

question:
A 3-month-old Jewish infant is brought to the emergency department because of a generalized seizure 1 hour
ago. He is lethargic, weighs 2.7kg (6lb), and has a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities,
and a protuberant abdomen. His liver is felt 5cm (2in) below the right costal margin. His kidneys are
enlarged. His blood sugar level is 40mg/dL. His serum uric acid, total cholesterol, triglycerides and lactic
acid levels are elevated. The levels of his liver transaminases are normal. What is the most likely cause of
this infant's symptoms?
options: C. Deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme activity
D. Deficiency of branching enzyme activity
explanation:
Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is also known as type I glycogen storage disease and Von-Gierke's
disease. As its name suggests, this condition is caused by deficient glucose-6-phosphatase in the liver,
kidneys, and intestinal mucosa. The typical patient, as described in the vignette, is 3-4 months of age with
hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia. Hypoglycemic seizures may occur. The
characteristic features include a doll-like face (i.e., fat cheeks), thin extremities, short stature, and a
protuberant abdomen (due to the enlarged liver and kidneys). The spleen and heart are normal.
(Choice B) Acid maltase deficiency is also known as type II glycogen storage disease and Pompes'
disease. Although patients with this condition also have hepatomegaly, they usually present in the first few
weeks of life as a "floppy baby" with feeding difficulties, macroglossia, and heart failure (due to progressive
hypertrophic cardiomyopathy).
(Choice C) Type III glycogen storage disease is caused by a deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme
activity. Similar clinical manifestations (e.g., hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and growth
retardation) may make it initially difficult to distinguish from type I glycogen storage disease; however, their
laboratory findings differ. Patients with glycogen storage III disease have elevated levels of liver
transaminases, fasting ketosis, and normal blood lactate and uric acid concentrations. Other pertinent
findings are splenomegaly and normal kidneys.
(Choice D) Deficiency of branching enzyme activity results in type IV glycogen storage disease or
amylopectinosis. The typical patient is in his first 18 months of life with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to
thrive. The most common pathology is progressive cirrhosis of the liver.
(Choice E) Patients with liver phosphorylase deficiency have a benign course, and typically present with
hepatomegaly and growth retardation early in childhood. Mild hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperketosis
may occur. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.
Educational Objective:
The typical patient with glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic
acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia. The characteristic appearance is a doll-like face (i.e. fat
cheeks), thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen (due to the enlarged liver and kidneys).
Hypoglycemic seizures may occur.

question:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office due to headaches and impaired walking. These symptoms started
seven days ago, and progressed gradually. He just recently recovered from otitis media that was
superimposed on an acute respiratory infection. His past medical history is significant for three episodes of
otitis media and one episode of pneumonia. His temperature is 36.7C(98F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm
Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination reveals mild right-sided hemiparesis
and a slightly dilated left pupil. The funduscopic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The onset of headaches, accompanied by focal neurologic symptoms soon after an episode of acute otitis
media, is highly suggestive of a brain abscess. Although the incidence of otogenic brain abscess is
declining, otitis media still remains as an important cause of brain abscesses. Headaches are the most
common symptom of brain abscess, but are very non-specific. Focal neurologic signs develop in 50% of
patients, usually days to weeks after the onset of headaches. Fever is present in less than half of the
patients with a brain abscess; therefore, it is not a reliable sign. Papilledema on funduscopic examination is a
later sign and indicates significant cerebral edema; it is observed in 25% of patients. Other diagnoses listed
are less likely in this patient. CT or MRI scan will show ring-enhancing lesions.
(Choice A) Todd's palsy is characterized by transient hemiplegia that occurs after a seizure.
(Choices B, C and D) Patients with brain tumors rarely present with such a short history of the disease.
Furthermore, papilledema is a characteristic finding of this disease.
(Choice F) The absence of fever makes the diagnosis of meningitis unlikely.
(Choices H and I) Stroke is a rare cause of neurologic abnormalities in children, and an obvious cause or
precipitating factor is usually present (e.g., congenital heart disease).
(Choice K) Carotid artery dissection typically develops after trauma.
Educational Objective:
A patient with an acute onset of headaches and focal neurologic symptoms after an episode of acute otitis
media or sinusitis most likely has a brain abscess. Ring-enhancing lesions are usually seen on CT or MRI
scan.

question:
A 6-year-old Caucasian boy is brought by his mother to the office due to abdominal pain for the past 3-4
days. He denies nausea, vomiting, and any change in bowel habits. Physical examination reveals a diffusely
tender abdomen without any focal signs. There is a maculopapular rash on his lower extremities. His right
knee is tender to palpation and passive movement. His initial labs show:
CBC
Hb                                    13.5g/dL
Ht                                     38%
MCV                                  86 fL
Platelet count                      350,000/cmm
Leukocyte count                   8,000/cmm
Segmented neutrophils         68%
Bands                            1%
Eosinophils                      1%
Lymphocytes                    24%
Monocytes                       6%
Serum
Serum Na                          140 mEq/L
Serum K                           3.6 mEq/L
Chloride                            98 mEq/L
Bicarbonates                       23 mEq/L
BUN                                18 mg/dL
Serum Creatinine                  1.3 mg/dL
Calcium                            9.2 mg/dL
Blood Glucose                     118 mg/dL
Urinalysis
Specific gravity                     1.020
Blood                                 4+
Protein                               1+
Glucose                              Negative
Ketones                              Negative
Leukocyte esterase                Negative
Nitrites                               Negative
Which of the following glomerular abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
options: E. Linear deposition of IgG on the basement membrane
explanation:
This boy has Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP), which is an IgA mediated vasculitis of small vessels. HSP
occurs more often in children than in adults, and many cases follow an upper respiratory tract infection,
suggesting that the precipitating antigen may be infectious. The clinical manifestations include a classic
tetrad of rash, arthralgias, abdominal pain, and renal disease. This tetrad can occur in any order and at any
time over a period of several days to several weeks. The rash is typically purpuric and distributed
symmetrically over the lower legs, buttocks and arms. Arthralgias most commonly affect the knees and
ankles. These symptoms are always transient, and there is no permanent damage to the joints.
Gastrointestinal symptoms are present in the majority of patients, and most commonly include colicky
abdominal pain (presumably due to local vasculitis) that is frequently associated with vomiting. Renal
involvement is common and not necessarily related to the severity of extrarenal involvement. Most patients
have relatively mild disease characterized by asymptomatic hematuria and proteinuria with a normal or only
slightly elevated plasma creatinine concentration; however, more marked findings may occur including the
nephrotic syndrome, hypertension, and acute renal failure. In addition, other organs or systems, such as the
lung and central nervous system, may be involved. Confirmation of the diagnosis requires evidence of tissue
deposition in the skin or kidney of IgA by immunofluorescence microscopy.
(Choice A) Podocyte fusion is typically seen in minimal change disease via electron microscopy.
(Choice B) Glomerular basement thickening is a feature of membranous nephropathy, which is the most
common cause of adult nephrotic syndrome.
(Choice C) Focal and segmental sclerosis is typical for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
(Choice E) Linear deposition of IgG on the basement membrane is seen in Goodpasture's syndrome.
Educational Objective:
Henoch-Schonlein Purpura is an IgA-mediated vasculitis of small vessels, which results in rashes,
arthralgias, abdominal pain and renal disease. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals IgA deposition in the
kidney.

question:
A 1-day-old male infant has bilious vomiting after every feeding. He hasn't passed any stools yet. He had no
prenatal care, and was delivered vaginally at term. He weighs 3kg (6.6lb), and his APGAR scores were 6 and
7 at 1 min and 5 min, respectively. On examination, the neonate is hypotonic, he has a flat facial profile, short
ears with downfolding ear lobes, a single palmar crease, and a depressed fontanel. There is abdominal
distention which is most prominent in the upper abdomen. His abdominal x-rays show gastric and duodenal
gas distension with no air distally. What other anomaly can also be expected in this infant?
explanation:
The clinical picture is consistent with Down's syndrome, and this newborn is most likely suffering from
duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia is the most common gastrointestinal anomaly in Down's syndrome
patients. Typically a "double bubble sign" is seen on abdominal radiograph. Other GI malformations that can
occur are:
Hirschsprung's disease
Esophageal atresia
Pyloric stenosis
Malrotation of the bowel
Congenital heart disease is the most common cause of death in childhood. The common cardiac defects
that can occur are:
Endocardial cushion defect
Ventricular septal defect
Patent ductus arteriosus
(Choices A, B, D & E) Sigmoid volvulus, meconium plug syndrome, intussusception and Meckel's
diverticulum are not associated with Down's syndrome.
Educational Objective:
Patients with Down's syndrome are more likely to develop duodenal atresia, Hirschsprung's disease,
endocardial cushion defects and acute leukemias.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because his grades are deteriorating. According to the
mother, the child is always preoccupied and prefers to play with "part of the toy rather than the entire toy." The
child's IQ is 55. On examination, the child has a very poor attention span. He has a prominent jaw, long ears
and large testicles. What is the most likely cause for this child's mental retardation?
options: C. Increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats
explanation:
Affected males of Fragile X syndrome may have a characteristic appearance (large head, long face,
prominent forehead and chin, protruding ears), joint laxity, and large testes. Behavioral abnormalities,
including hyperactivity, short attention span, and autism, are common. The syndrome results from a full
mutation in the FMR1 gene caused by an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats accompanied by
aberrant methylation of the FMR1 gene.
(Choices D and E) Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autistic disorder may be presenting features of
Fragile X syndrome, but by themselves do not explain the other clinical findings in this child.
(Choice B) Fetal alcohol syndrome is characterized by mild to moderate mental retardation, hypo-plastic
maxilla, long philtrum and microcephaly.
(Choice A) Down's syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, microcephaly, flat occiput, Simian
crease, endocardial cushion defects, prominent tongue, epicanthal folds with slanting eyes, and Brush field's
spots on the periphery of the iris.
Educational Objective:
Fragile X syndrome is characterized by low to normal IQ with learning disabilities, generalized language
disability, short attention span, autism, large head, prominent jaw, large low set ears and macroorchidism.

question:
A 15-year-old African-American girl has a facial rash and vague joint pains. Her temperature is 37.2C(99F).
On examination, a malar erythematous rash is noted. Her laboratory evaluation is significant for
anemia, leukopenia, and a normal platelet count. Her antinuclear antibody and Rapid Plasma Reagin (RPR)
tests are positive. Which of the following tests is confirmatory for this patient's condition?
options: A. VDRL (Veneral Disease Research Laboratory) test
explanation:
The child has features suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). One-fifth of all SLE cases occur
in children. The confirmatory tests are anti-Smith antibody test and anti-double stranded DNA (dsDNA) test.
(Choice D) Coomb's test is used for the diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Although it may be
positive in patients with SLE, it is not useful in confirming the diagnosis.
(Choice E) Bone marrow examination is also not useful in confirming the diagnosis of SLE.
(Choices A and B) SLE is often associated with false positive RPR test results. RPR (Rapid Plasma
Reagin) and VDRL tests are used in the diagnosis of syphilis, but both have high false positive rates in
patients with SLE. The FTA test is more specific for the diagnosis of syphilis, but is of no use in SLE.
Educational Objective:
Positive anti-Smith antibodies and/or anti-double stranded DNA antibodies is specific and confirmatory for the
diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is rushed to the emergency department after falling on his outstretched hand. He
immediately complained of right arm pain after the accident, and he currently cannot move his arm due to
the pain. He is crying and holding his right arm in flexion. There is ecchymosis just above his elbow. He
cries out in pain when his arm is moved. An x-ray reveals a supracondylar fracture. What secondary
injury is most commonly associated with this patient's fracture?
explanation:
Supracondylar fractures are the most common fractures in the pediatric population. It is rarely seen in adults,
and the majority result from trauma. The most common complication is entrapment of the brachial artery,
resulting in loss of the radial artery pulse; therefore, all patients with a supracondylar fracture must have their
radial pulse checked. After reduction of the fracture, the radial pulse must be reassessed.
(Choice A) The median nerve is spared in a supracondylar fracture. Once the fracture is reduced, the
edema subsides and the paresthesias in the arm subside.
(Choice B) The axillary artery is injured during proximal humerus fractures, but not with supracondylar
fractures.
(Choice C) The ulnar artery is not directly injured with supracondylar fractures. If the brachial artery is
compromised with the fracture, the ulnar pulse will disappear.
(Choice E) Brachial plexus injury is not common with supracondylar fractures.
Educational Objective:
With supracondylar fractures, the brachial artery can be compromised, resulting in the loss of the radial
artery pulse; therefore, the radial artery pulse must be assessed when the fracture is reduced.
